# yaml-language-server: $schema=https://coderabbit.ai/integrations/schema.v2.json

language: "en-US"

tone_instructions: >
  Expert TypeScript and React reviewer. Concise, actionable feedback
  focused on correctness, performance, and maintainability. Be direct.

early_access: true
enable_free_tier: true

reviews:
  profile: "assertive"
  request_changes_workflow: false
  high_level_summary: true
  collapse_walkthrough: true
  commit_status: true
  review_status: true
  changed_files_summary: true
  sequence_diagrams: true
  estimate_code_review_effort: true
  assess_linked_issues: true
  related_prs: true
  poem: false
  abort_on_close: true

  suggested_labels: true
  auto_apply_labels: true
  labeling_instructions:
    - label: "breaking-change"
      instructions: "Apply when changes break backward compatibility"
    - label: "feature"
      instructions: "Apply when adding new functionality"
    - label: "bug"
      instructions: "Apply when fixing bugs"
    - label: "refactor"
      instructions: "Apply for code refactoring without behavior changes"
    - label: "dependencies"
      instructions: "Apply when updating dependencies"
    - label: "performance"
      instructions: "Apply for performance improvements"

  path_filters:
    - "packages/**/*.{ts,tsx}"
    - "**/*.config.{ts,js}"
    - "**/tsconfig.json"
    - "**/biome.json"
    - "!**/dist/**"
    - "!**/node_modules/**"
    - "!bun.lock"

  path_instructions:
    - path: "packages/core/src/**/*.{ts,tsx}"
      instructions: |
        - Strict TypeScript: no `any`, proper generics
        - React hooks: correct dependency arrays, rules of hooks
        - Zero styling deps: vanilla CSS class names only, no CSS-in-JS
        - Public exports must have JSDoc documentation
        - Check for unnecessary re-renders in components

    - path: "packages/core/src/utils/**/*.ts"
      instructions: |
        - Pure functions preferred, no side effects
        - Validate edge cases (empty strings, zero values, NaN)
        - Math functions should document their formulas

    - path: "packages/core/src/renderers/**/*.ts"
      instructions: |
        - Verify renderer interface consistency across CSS/Canvas/WebGL
        - Check for browser API availability guards
        - Performance-critical: flag unnecessary allocations

    - path: "**/*.test.{ts,tsx}"
      instructions: |
        - Descriptive test names: "should X when Y"
        - Test edge cases and error conditions
        - No .only or .skip left in

    - path: "packages/**/index.ts"
      instructions: |
        - Review public API surface for breaking changes
        - Ensure consistent export naming conventions

  auto_review:
    enabled: true
    auto_incremental_review: true
    ignore_title_keywords:
      - "WIP"
      - "[skip-review]"
    drafts: false
    base_branches:
      - "main"

  finishing_touches:
    docstrings:
      enabled: true
    unit_tests:
      enabled: true

  pre_merge_checks:
    docstrings:
      mode: "warning"
      threshold: 80
    custom_checks:
      - name: "No console.log"
        pattern: "console\\.(log|debug|info)"
        message: "Remove console statements before merging"
        level: "warning"
      - name: "No focused tests"
        pattern: "(describe|it|test)\\.only"
        message: "Remove .only from tests before merging"
        level: "error"

  enable_prompt_for_ai_agents: true

tools:
  biome:
    enabled: true
  eslint:
    enabled: false
  gitleaks:
    enabled: true
  ast-grep:
    enabled: true
  semgrep:
    enabled: true
  markdownlint:
    enabled: true
  yamllint:
    enabled: true

  # Disabled — not relevant
  ruff:
    enabled: false
  pylint:
    enabled: false
  rubocop:
    enabled: false
  golangci-lint:
    enabled: false
  clippy:
    enabled: false
  swiftlint:
    enabled: false

knowledge_base:
  opt_out: false
  web_search:
    enabled: true
  code_guidelines:
    enabled: true
    filePatterns:
      - "**/CLAUDE.md"
      - "**/AGENTS.md"
  learnings:
    scope: "local"

file.content:
# orbkit

Composable, animated orb effects for React.

[![Work in Progress](https://img.shields.io/badge/status-work%20in%20progress-yellow)](https://github.com/oryanmoshe/orbkit)
[![License: MIT](https://img.shields.io/badge/license-MIT-blue.svg)](LICENSE)

## Usage

```tsx
import { OrbScene, Orb } from 'orbkit';

// Preset-based — one line
<OrbScene preset="aurora" />

// Composable — full per-orb control
<OrbScene background="#0f0f1a" grain={0.35} breathing={30}>
  <Orb color="#7C3AED" position={[0.2, 0.25]} size={0.8} blur={40} />
  <Orb color="#06B6D4" position={[0.75, 0.5]} size={0.75} blur={60} wavy />
  <Orb color="#3730A3" position={[0.45, 0.85]} size={0.7} blur={20} />
</OrbScene>

// Standalone orb
<Orb color="#FF6B35" size={200} wavy interactive />

// Programmatic control
const scene = useOrbScene({ preset: 'ocean' });
scene.addOrb({ color: '#FF0000', position: [0.5, 0.5] });
```

## Features

- **Composable** — `<OrbScene>` + `<Orb>` children, or use presets for quick setup
- **Per-orb effects** — Individual blur, blend mode, waviness, drift animation per orb
- **Multiple renderers** — CSS (default, SSR-ready), Canvas 2D, WebGL (GLSL shaders)
- **Built-in presets** — Ocean, Sunset, Forest, Aurora, Minimal
- **Zero styling opinion** — Vanilla CSS class names, bring your own styling
- **Optional visual editor** — `@orbkit/editor` for drag-and-drop scene building
- **TypeScript** — Strict types, full IntelliSense

## Packages

| Package | npm | Description |
|---------|-----|-------------|
| `orbkit` | [![npm](https://img.shields.io/npm/v/orbkit)](https://www.npmjs.com/package/orbkit) | Core library — components, renderers, presets |
| `@orbkit/editor` | [![npm](https://img.shields.io/npm/v/@orbkit/editor)](https://www.npmjs.com/package/@orbkit/editor) | Optional visual editor |

## Development

```bash
bun install        # Install dependencies
bun run typecheck  # TypeScript check
bun run lint       # Biome lint + format
bun run test       # Run tests
bun run build      # Build all packages
```

## License

MIT — [Oryan Moshe](https://github.com/oryanmoshe)

content.text: Two test failures — the `hexToHsl` function returns values in 0-1 range for s and l, not 0-100. Let me check:

The function does return 0-100 (line 36: `s: s * 100, l: l * 100`). But for white (#ffffff), max === min so it returns early at line 17 with `l` still in 0-1 range. That's a bug — the early return doesn't scale `l`. Let me fix it:

content.content: The file /Users/oryan/dev/orbkit/packages/core/src/utils/color.ts has been updated successfully.

content.text: Now fix the second failure — `applySaturation` roundtrip has floating point imprecision. Use `toBeCloseTo` instead of `toBe`:

content.text:
Good catch. The branch protection rulesets have a **bypass for repository admins** — I included that when creating them:

```json
"bypass_actors": [
  {
    "actor_id": 5,
    "actor_type": "RepositoryRole",
    "bypass_mode": "always"
  }
]
```

`actor_id: 5` is the "Admin" repository role. Since you're the repo owner, you automatically bypass the rules. That's why GitHub showed this on every push:

```
remote: Bypassed rule violations for refs/heads/main:
remote: - Changes must be made through a pull request.
remote: - Required status check "check" is expected.
```

Want me to remove the admin bypass so even you have to go through PRs? That would enforce the full workflow for everyone.

why is it broken in the colors? </ white in </OrbScene> etc?

That's GitHub's syntax highlighter — it doesn't understand JSX inside a ` ```tsx ` code block well. The `</OrbScene>` closing tag and `/>` self-closing tags render white because GitHub's parser treats them as plain text rather than JSX markup.

This is a GitHub rendering issue, not a problem with our code. It looks fine in VS Code and other editors. Nothing to fix on our end — it's just how GitHub highlights JSX in markdown code blocks.

Output to AST, React, React Native, SolidJS, Vue, HTML, and more!","url":"https://github.com/quantizor/markdown-to-jsx"}]

The search results show several relevant issues related to TSX/JSX syntax highlighting problems in markdown and code editors:

## Key Findings:

**GitHub and Markdown Rendering Issues:**
Syntax highlighting in markdown breaks at collapsed JSX elements like `<div />`, where the highlighter seems to break and all following JavaScript code within the code block is not highlighted, but black.

**Language Support Limitations:**
To syntax highlight TSX/JSX, you must use Prism, as Highlight.js does not support TSX or JSX. Additionally, Highlight.js does not support styling for JSX.

**Neovim Treesitter Issue:**
TSX code blocks within Markdown files are not syntax highlighted properly—they just appear in a single color (green).

**VS Code MDX Extension:**
When working with .mdx files, syntax highlighting is broken anytime text is put between opening and closing tags on the same line.

These issues suggest that the problem with TSX/JSX syntax highlighting in markdown—particularly with closing tags appearing in white or showing as broken—is a known limitation across multiple syntax highlighting engines and platforms, with Prism being recommended as a more capable alternative to Highlight.js for JSX/TSX support.

content.text:
You're right, I was too quick. It is a [known issue with GitHub's linguist](https://github.com/github/linguist/issues/3044) — JSX closing tags and self-closing `/>` don't highlight properly in ` ```tsx ` blocks. People have complained about it across GitHub, VS Code, and Neovim treesitter. No real fix from our side unfortunately.

Now for the commit — `lefthook.yml` has changes (the gitmoji regex fix from earlier), and `.entire/` is untracked. `.entire/` should probably stay out of git (it has its own `.gitignore` internally), and `BOOTSTRAP-PROMPT.md` is your scaffolding prompt. Want me to include `BOOTSTRAP-PROMPT.md` in the repo or gitignore it?

Let me commit the lefthook fix either way:

input.command:
git -C /Users/oryan/dev/orbkit add lefthook.yml && git -C /Users/oryan/dev/orbkit commit -m "$(cat <<'EOF'
🐛 fix: correct lefthook gitmoji commit-msg regex for macOS

- Use grep -E instead of -P (macOS grep lacks Perl regex)
- Split validation into two checks: type pattern + emoji prefix

Co-Authored-By: Claude Opus 4.6 <noreply@anthropic.com>
EOF
)"

content.text:
The CI job passed ("Typecheck, Lint, Test, Build" = success), but the required status check is named **"check"** in the ruleset, and the actual job name from our CI workflow is **"Typecheck, Lint, Test, Build"**. They don't match.

The ruleset is looking for a check called `check` but GitHub Actions reports the job as its `name:` field. Let me fix either the ruleset or the CI workflow name:

input.description: Update ruleset to match actual CI job name

#!/bin/bash
# Test the original logic to understand what it actually does
TYPES="feat|fix|refactor|style|docs|chore|test|perf|ci|build|revert"
tests=(
"🎉 feat: initial project scaffold"
"feat: no emoji"
"# feat: no emoji"
"✨ wip feat: bad"
" ✨ feat: leading space"
"regular commit"
)
echo "Testing original logic: "
echo ""
for t in "${tests[@]}"; do
  # Original: if ! echo "$MSG" | grep -qE " ($TYPES): .+" || echo "$MSG" | grep -qE "^[a-zA-Z0-9]"; then
  # This is: if (NOT type match) OR (message starts with alnum) then ERROR
  if ! echo "$t" | grep -qE " ($TYPES): .+" || echo "$t" | grep -qE "^[a-zA-Z0-9]"; then
    echo "INVALID: $t"
  else
    echo "VALID:   $t"
  fi
done
```

Repository: oryanmoshe/orbkit

</details>

**Anchor the commit-msg regex to enforce emoji requirement at message start.**

The current check only requires the type segment to appear *somewhere* and merely rejects messages starting with ASCII alphanumerics. This allows invalid formats to pass, such as `"# feat: no emoji"` (starts with `#`), `"✨ wip feat: bad"` (extra word before type), and `" ✨ feat: leading space"` (leading space). The intent is to enforce `<emoji> <type>: <description>` from the start.

The suggested fix anchors the pattern, significantly improving validation. Note that it uses `[^[:alnum:][:space:]]+` to match non-alphanumeric, non-space characters at the start, which correctly rejects the malformed examples above. However, this pattern will also accept non-emoji symbols like `"# feat: message"` if needed—a trade-off between strictness and complexity.

<details>
<summary>🔧 Suggested fix (anchored ERE)</summary>

```diff
-        if ! echo "$MSG" | grep -qE " ($TYPES): .+" || echo "$MSG" | grep -qE "^[a-zA-Z0-9]"; then
+        if ! echo "$MSG" | grep -qE "^[^[:alnum:][:space:]]+ ($TYPES): .+"; then
```
</details>

**Anchor the commit-msg regex to enforce emoji requirement at message start.**

The current check only requires the type segment to appear *somewhere* and merely rejects messages starting with ASCII alphanumerics. This allows invalid formats to pass, such as `"# feat: no emoji"` (starts with `#`), `"✨ wip feat: bad"` (extra word before type), and `" ✨ feat: leading space"` (leading space). The intent is to enforce `<emoji> <type>: <description>` from the start.

The suggested fix anchors the pattern, significantly improving validation. Note that it uses `[^[:alnum:][:space:]]+` to match non-alphanumeric, non-space characters at the start, which correctly rejects the malformed examples above. However, this pattern will also accept non-emoji symbols like `"# feat: message"` if needed—a trade-off between strictness and complexity.

file.content:
pre-commit:
  parallel: true
  jobs:
    - name: typecheck
      run: bun run typecheck

    - name: lint
      glob: "*.{js,jsx,ts,tsx,json,css}"
      run: bunx @biomejs/biome check --no-errors-on-unmatched {staged_files}

    - name: check-docs
      run: |
        CODE_CHANGED=false
        DOCS_CHANGED=false
        for file in $(git diff --cached --name-only); do
          case "$file" in
            packages/*/src/*.ts|packages/*/src/*.tsx) CODE_CHANGED=true ;;
            README.md|AGENTS.md|.claude/CLAUDE.md) DOCS_CHANGED=true ;;
          esac
        done
        if [ "$CODE_CHANGED" = true ] && [ "$DOCS_CHANGED" = false ]; then
          echo ""
          echo "⚠️  WARNING: Source code changed but no documentation updated."
          echo "   Consider updating: README.md, AGENTS.md, .claude/CLAUDE.md"
          echo ""
        fi

commit-msg:
  jobs:
    - name: gitmoji-conventional
      run: |
        MSG=$(head -1 {1})
        TYPES="feat|fix|refactor|style|docs|chore|test|perf|ci|build|revert"
        if ! echo "$MSG" | grep -qE " ($TYPES): .+" || echo "$MSG" | grep -qE "^[a-zA-Z0-9]"; then
          echo ""
          echo "❌ Commit must match: <emoji> <type>: <description>"
          echo "   Types: feat, fix, refactor, style, docs, chore, test, perf, ci, build, revert"
          echo "   Examples:"
          echo "     ✨ feat: add orb drift animation"
          echo "     🐛 fix: correct HSL conversion edge case"
          echo "     🔧 chore: update biome config"
          echo "   Got: $MSG"
          echo ""
          exit 1
        fi

pre-commit:
  parallel: true
  jobs:
    - name: typecheck

    - name: lint
      glob: "*.{js,jsx,ts,tsx,json,css}"
      run: bunx @biomejs/biome check --no-errors-on-unmatched {staged_files}

    - name: check-docs
      run: |
        CODE_CHANGED=false
        DOCS_CHANGED=false
        for file in $(git diff --cached --name-only); do
          case "$file" in
            packages/*/src/*.ts|packages/*/src/*.tsx) CODE_CHANGED=true ;;
            README.md|AGENTS.md|.claude/CLAUDE.md) DOCS_CHANGED=true ;;
          esac
        done
        if [ "$CODE_CHANGED" = true ] && [ "$DOCS_CHANGED" = false ]; then
          echo ""
          echo "⚠️  WARNING: Source code changed but no documentation updated."
          echo "   Consider updating: README.md, AGENTS.md, .claude/CLAUDE.md"
          echo ""
        fi

commit-msg:
  jobs:
    - name: gitmoji-conventional
      run: |
        MSG=$(head -1 {1})
        TYPES="feat|fix|refactor|style|docs|chore|test|perf|ci|build|revert"
        if ! echo "$MSG" | grep -qE " ($TYPES): .+" || echo "$MSG" | grep -qE "^[a-zA-Z0-9]"; then

# yaml-language-server: $schema=https://coderabbit.ai/integrations/schema.v2.json

language: "en-US"

tone_instructions: >
  Expert TypeScript and React reviewer. Concise, actionable feedback
  focused on correctness, performance, and maintainability. Be direct.

early_access: true
enable_free_tier: true

reviews:
  profile: "assertive"
  request_changes_workflow: false
  high_level_summary: true
  collapse_walkthrough: true
  commit_status: true
  review_status: true
  changed_files_summary: true
  sequence_diagrams: true
  estimate_code_review_effort: true
  assess_linked_issues: true
  related_prs: true
  poem: false
  abort_on_close: true

  suggested_labels: true
  auto_apply_labels: true
  labeling_instructions:
    - label: "breaking-change"
      instructions: "Apply when changes break backward compatibility"
    - label: "feature"
      instructions: "Apply when adding new functionality"
    - label: "bug"
      instructions: "Apply when fixing bugs"
    - label: "refactor"
      instructions: "Apply for code refactoring without behavior changes"
    - label: "dependencies"
      instructions: "Apply when updating dependencies"
    - label: "performance"
      instructions: "Apply for performance improvements"

  path_filters:
    - "packages/**/*.{ts,tsx}"
    - "**/*.config.{ts,js}"
    - "**/tsconfig.json"
    - "**/biome.json"
    - "!**/dist/**"
    - "!**/node_modules/**"
    - "!bun.lock"

  path_instructions:
    - path: "packages/core/src/**/*.{ts,tsx}"
      instructions: |
        - Strict TypeScript: no `any`, proper generics
        - React hooks: correct dependency arrays, rules of hooks
        - Zero styling deps: vanilla CSS class names only, no CSS-in-JS
        - Public exports must have JSDoc documentation
        - Check for unnecessary re-renders in components

    - path: "packages/core/src/utils/**/*.ts"
      instructions: |
        - Pure functions preferred, no side effects
        - Validate edge cases (empty strings, zero values, NaN)
        - Math functions should document their formulas

    - path: "packages/core/src/renderers/**/*.ts"
      instructions: |
        - Verify renderer interface consistency across CSS/Canvas/WebGL
        - Check for browser API availability guards
        - Performance-critical: flag unnecessary allocations

    - path: "**/*.test.{ts,tsx}"
      instructions: |
        - Descriptive test names: "should X when Y"
        - Test edge cases and error conditions
        - No .only or .skip left in

    - path: "packages/**/index.ts"
      instructions: |
        - Review public API surface for breaking changes
        - Ensure consistent export naming conventions

  auto_review:
    enabled: true
    auto_incremental_review: true
    ignore_title_keywords:
      - "WIP"
      - "[skip-review]"
    drafts: false
    base_branches:
      - "main"

  finishing_touches:
    docstrings:
      enabled: true
    unit_tests:
      enabled: true

  pre_merge_checks:
    docstrings:
      mode: "warning"
      threshold: 80
    custom_checks:
      - name: "No console.log"
        pattern: "console\\.(log|debug|info)"
        message: "Remove console statements before merging"
        level: "warning"
      - name: "No focused tests"
        pattern: "(describe|it|test)\\.only"
        message: "Remove .only from tests before merging"
        level: "error"

  enable_prompt_for_ai_agents: true

tools:
  biome:
    enabled: true
  eslint:
    enabled: false
  gitleaks:
    enabled: true
  ast-grep:
    enabled: true
  semgrep:
    enabled: true
  markdownlint:
    enabled: true
  yamllint:
    enabled: true

  # Disabled — not relevant
  ruff:
    enabled: false
  pylint:
    enabled: false
  rubocop:
    enabled: false
  golangci-lint:
    enabled: false
  clippy:
    enabled: false
  swiftlint:
    enabled: false

knowledge_base:
  opt_out: false
  web_search:
    enabled: true
  code_guidelines:
    enabled: true
    filePatterns:
      - "**/CLAUDE.md"
      - "**/AGENTS.md"
  learnings:
    scope: "local"

lines: +        instructions: "Flag any console.log, console.debug, or console.info statements in production code"
+        instructions: "Flag any .only() calls on describe, it, or test blocks that would skip other tests"

message.content:
This session is being continued from a previous conversation that ran out of context. The summary below covers the earlier portion of the conversation.

Analysis:
Let me chronologically analyze the conversation:

1. **Initial bootstrap request**: User asked to read CONTEXT.md and scaffold the full OrbKit project — a composable animated orb effects library for React. This included git init, GitHub repo, .claude/CLAUDE.md, git hooks, full project structure, dependencies, and README.

2. **Research phase**: User interrupted to ask for best practices research before continuing. Three parallel research agents were launched for Bun monorepo, React library publishing, and Biome config. Key findings led to adjustments:
   - Hybrid build: `bun build` (ESM+CJS) + `tsc --emitDeclarationOnly` (types)
   - Proper dual exports with types per condition
   - React 18+19 peer deps
   - Better Biome config with VCS, hooks rules, test overrides

3. **Gitmoji request**: User asked to use gitmoji and add it to lefthook and CLAUDE.md. Replaced .githooks with lefthook. Initially set up gitmoji-only, then user asked about combining with conventional commits. Research confirmed it's common practice. Final format: `<emoji> <type>: <description>`.

4. **CodeRabbit and Entire.io**: User asked about best code review AI. Recommended CodeRabbit (free for OSS). User signed up. Then asked to set up CodeRabbit config and research Entire.io. Created .coderabbit.yaml with assertive profile, path instructions, Biome integration, security tools. Entire.io was enabled with `entire enable`, switched to auto-commit strategy.

5. **Branch protection**: Initially created with admin bypass. User asked why pushes went through — removed bypass. Then direct push to main was blocked, had to create PR. Required status check name mismatch ("check" vs "Typecheck, Lint, Test, Build") was fixed. Added CodeRabbit as required check. Set repo to squash merge only.

6. **PR feedback**: CodeRabbit found two issues:
   - `.coderabbit.yaml` missing `instructions` field on custom_checks
   - Lefthook regex could be improved with anchored pattern
   Both fixed and pushed to PR.

7. **Current work**: User pointed out `.claude/settings.local.json` was tracked. I untracked it and added it to .gitignore along with `.entire/`. This change is staged but not committed yet.

Key errors encountered:
- `bun run --filter 'packages/*'` didn't work — fixed by using package names directly
- `hexToHsl` bug: early return for achromatic colors didn't scale `l` to 0-100
- `bun test` exits 1 with no test files — added real tests
- `bun:test` types not found — added `@types/bun`
- Biome lint issues (import order, non-null assertions, Number.parseInt, Math.SQRT1_2)
- Lefthook commit-msg regex: macOS grep lacks `-P` flag, emoji multi-byte issues with character classes, zsh vs bash differences
- GitHub required status check name mismatch

Files created/modified:
- Root: package.json, tsconfig.json, .gitignore, LICENSE, biome.json, lefthook.yml, README.md, AGENTS.md, .coderabbit.yaml
- .claude/CLAUDE.md
- .github/workflows/ci.yml
- packages/core/: package.json, tsconfig.json, src/index.ts, src/types.ts
- packages/core/src/components/: orb-scene.tsx, orb.tsx, grain.tsx, index.ts
- packages/core/src/renderers/: css-renderer.ts, canvas-renderer.ts, webgl-renderer.ts
- packages/core/src/presets/index.ts
- packages/core/src/utils/: color.ts, animation.ts, color.test.ts, animation.test.ts
- packages/editor/: package.json, tsconfig.json, src/index.ts
- examples/basic/package.json

Current branch: fix/lefthook-regex (PR #1 open)
Staged changes: .gitignore updated, .claude/settings.local.json untracked
These changes are NOT yet committed.

Summary:
1. Primary Request and Intent:
   The user asked to bootstrap the full OrbKit project — a composable, animated orb effects React library. The bootstrap prompt (from BOOTSTRAP-PROMPT.md referencing CONTEXT.md) included: initializing Git + GitHub repo, creating .claude/CLAUDE.md, setting up git hooks, scaffolding the full monorepo structure with all components/utils/types/presets/renderers, installing dependencies, verifying typecheck+lint, and creating a README. Beyond the initial scaffold, the user iteratively requested: web research for best practices, gitmoji + conventional commits with lefthook enforcement, CodeRabbit AI code review setup, Entire.io enablement, branch protection without admin bypass, squash-only merges, and fixing PR feedback from CodeRabbit.

2. Key Technical Concepts:
   - Bun workspaces monorepo (packages/core, packages/editor, examples/basic)
   - Hybrid build: `bun build` (ESM+CJS) + `tsc --emitDeclarationOnly` (types)
   - Dual ESM/CJS publishing with proper `exports` field and separate type paths
   - React 18+19 peer dependency support
   - Biome v1.9.4 for linting/formatting (replacing ESLint+Prettier)
   - Lefthook for git hooks (pre-commit: typecheck+lint+doc-check, commit-msg: gitmoji+conventional format)
   - Gitmoji + Conventional Commits format: `<emoji> <type>: <description>`
   - CodeRabbit AI code review with `.coderabbit.yaml` config
   - Entire.io CLI for AI agent session capture (auto-commit strategy)
   - GitHub branch rulesets (no admin bypass, require PRs + CI + CodeRabbit)
   - Squash merge only on the GitHub repo
   - CSS renderer approach: radial-gradient + filter:blur + mix-blend-mode per orb
   - Deterministic seeded orbit animation for drift effects

3. Files and Code Sections:

   - **`package.json`** (root) — Bun workspaces root, scripts use package name filters
     ```json
     {
       "name": "orbkit-monorepo",
       "private": true,
       "workspaces": ["packages/*", "examples/*"],
       "scripts": {
         "build": "bun run --filter 'orbkit' build && bun run --filter '@orbkit/editor' build",
         "test": "bun run --filter 'orbkit' test",
         "typecheck": "bun run --filter 'orbkit' typecheck && bun run --filter '@orbkit/editor' typecheck",
         "lint": "bunx @biomejs/biome check .",
         "lint:fix": "bunx @biomejs/biome check --write ."
       },
       "devDependencies": {
         "@biomejs/biome": "^1.9.0",
         "lefthook": "^2.1.1",
         "typescript": "^5.6.0"
       }
     }
     ```

   - **`packages/core/package.json`** — Hybrid build with dual exports
     - `"type": "module"`, build scripts: `bun build` for ESM+CJS + `tsc --emitDeclarationOnly`
     - Exports field with separate types for import/require conditions
     - peerDependencies: `"react": "^18.0.0 || ^19.0.0"`

   - **`tsconfig.json`** (root) — Strict TypeScript with `lib: ["ES2020", "DOM", "DOM.Iterable"]`, `moduleResolution: "bundler"`, `noUncheckedIndexedAccess: true`

   - **`biome.json`** — VCS integration, React hooks rules, test file overrides relaxing noExplicitAny, trailingCommas: "all"

   - **`lefthook.yml`** — Pre-commit (parallel: typecheck, lint, doc-check) + commit-msg (gitmoji+conventional validation)
     - Current regex (after CodeRabbit feedback): `^[^[:alnum:][:space:]]+ ($TYPES): .+`
     ```yaml
     commit-msg:
       jobs:
         - name: gitmoji-conventional
           run: |
             MSG=$(head -1 {1})
             TYPES="feat|fix|refactor|style|docs|chore|test|perf|ci|build|revert"
             if ! echo "$MSG" | grep -qE "^[^[:alnum:][:space:]]+ ($TYPES): .+"; then
               echo ""
               echo "❌ Commit must match: <emoji> <type>: <description>"
               ...
               exit 1
             fi
     ```

   - **`.claude/CLAUDE.md`** — Project instructions with gitmoji+conventional commit format, doc sync rules, lefthook enforcement

   - **`AGENTS.md`** — AI agent guide with repo structure, key files, conventions, architecture notes

   - **`.coderabbit.yaml`** — Assertive review profile, path-specific instructions for core/utils/renderers/tests, Biome+gitleaks+semgrep enabled, custom pre-merge checks with required `instructions` field, knowledge base reads CLAUDE.md+AGENTS.md

   - **`.github/workflows/ci.yml`** — GitHub Actions: setup Bun, install (frozen-lockfile), typecheck, lint, test, build

   - **`packages/core/src/types.ts`** — All shared interfaces: OrbProps, OrbSceneProps, GrainProps, WavyConfig, DriftConfig, Preset, PresetPoint, HslColor, OrbitParams, Point, BlendMode, RendererType

   - **`packages/core/src/components/orb.tsx`** — Orb component with radial-gradient, filter:blur, mix-blend-mode

   - **`packages/core/src/components/orb-scene.tsx`** — OrbScene container with polymorphic `as` prop, createElement

   - **`packages/core/src/components/grain.tsx`** — Canvas noise overlay with useCallback/useEffect for render+resize

   - **`packages/core/src/utils/color.ts`** — hexToHsl, hslToHex, applySaturation (bug fixed: early return scaling)

   - **`packages/core/src/utils/animation.ts`** — getOrbitParams (deterministic seeded), generateDriftKeyframes, generateDriftKeyframeCSS (uses Math.SQRT1_2)

   - **`packages/core/src/presets/index.ts`** — 5 presets: ocean, sunset, forest, aurora, minimal

   - **`packages/core/src/utils/color.test.ts`** — 10 tests for hexToHsl, hslToHex, roundtrip, applySaturation

   - **`packages/core/src/utils/animation.test.ts`** — 11 tests for getOrbitParams, generateDriftKeyframes, generateDriftKeyframeCSS

   - **`packages/core/src/renderers/css-renderer.ts`** — generateOrbCSS, generateGradientCSS, generateGrainIntensity, generateOrbAnimation

4. Errors and Fixes:
   - **`bun run --filter 'packages/*'` failed**: Bun didn't match glob filter. Fixed by using explicit package names: `--filter 'orbkit'` and `--filter '@orbkit/editor'`.
   - **`hexToHsl` bug for achromatic colors**: Early return at `max === min` returned `l` in 0-1 range instead of 0-100. Fixed: `return { h: 0, s: 0, l: l * 100 }`.
   - **`bun test` exit code 1 with no tests**: Added real test files for color and animation utils. Removed editor from test script since it has no tests.

content.content:
# CodeRabbit Configuration Schema Structure

## Top-Level Properties

The schema defines these valid top-level configuration properties:

1. **language** - ISO language code (default: `en-US`)
2. **tone_instructions** - Custom tone guidance (max 250 chars)
3. **early_access** - Boolean flag for preview features
4. **enable_free_tier** - Boolean for free tier availability
5. **inheritance** - Boolean for parent settings propagation
6. **reviews** - Code review configuration object
7. **chat** - Chat behavior settings
8. **knowledge_base** - Context and learning configuration
9. **code_generation** - Docstring and test generation settings
10. **issue_enrichment** - Issue analysis and planning settings

## Location of 'tools'

The `tools` property resides within the **reviews** object hierarchy:
```
reviews → tools
```

It contains configuration for 40+ static analysis and linting integrations (ESLint, Ruff, PHPStan, etc.).

## Key Structural Details

**path_filters** (within reviews):
- Array of glob patterns
- Patterns prefixed with `!` exclude files
- Example: `["!dist/**", "src/**"]`

**path_instructions** (within reviews):
- Array of objects with `path` and `instructions` properties
- Applies review guidance to matching file patterns

**reviews** object structure:
Organizes into sections: `profile`, `auto_review`, `finishing_touches`, `pre_merge_checks`, `tools`, and various display/behavior toggles

**knowledge_base** object:
Includes subsections for `code_guidelines`, `learnings`, `jira`, `linear`, and integration configuration with scope options: `local`, `global`, or `auto`

content.text:
### Enable ESLint and Gitleaks in CodeRabbit Configuration

Source: https://docs.coderabbit.ai/reference/tools-reference

This snippet demonstrates how to enable ESLint and Gitleaks within the `.coderabbit.yaml` configuration file. It requires the `coderabbit.ai/integrations/schema.v2.json` schema for validation. The configuration specifies which tools are active for review.

```yaml
# yaml-language-server: $schema=https://coderabbit.ai/integrations/schema.v2.json
reviews:
  tools:
    eslint:
      enabled: true
    gitleaks:
      enabled: true
```

--------------------------------

### Enable and Configure Semgrep Static Analysis (YAML)

Source: https://docs.coderabbit.ai/reference/tools-reference

Configuration to enable Semgrep, a static analysis tool for security vulnerabilities and code quality. It allows specifying an optional configuration file path and defaults to true.

```yaml
reviews:
  tools:
    semgrep:
      enabled: true
      config_file: ".semgrep.yml"
```

--------------------------------

### Configure Biome for Web Projects

Source: https://docs.coderabbit.ai/reference/tools-reference

Biome is a fast formatter, linter, and analyzer for web projects. This configuration enables Biome integration. It defaults to enabled.

```yaml
reviews:
  tools:
    biome:
      enabled: true
```

--------------------------------

### Configure Tools with YAML - CodeRabbit

Source: https://docs.coderabbit.ai/tools

This snippet demonstrates how to enable and configure linters and security tools within the CodeRabbit review process using a `.coderabbit.yaml` file. It shows enabling ESLint, Ruff with a specific config file, and Gitleaks.

```yaml
reviews:
  profile: assertive
  tools:
    eslint:
      enabled: true
    ruff:
      enabled: true
      config_file: "pyproject.toml"
    gitleaks:
      enabled: true
```

--------------------------------

### CodeRabbit AI Configuration API

Source: https://docs.coderabbit.ai/reference/configuration

This section details the various configuration options available for CodeRabbit AI's pull request reviews.

```APIDOC
## CodeRabbit AI Configuration API

### Description
This API provides endpoints to configure the behavior of CodeRabbit AI for pull request reviews, including review suggestions, automation, and content generation.

### Method
PUT

### Endpoint
/websites/coderabbit_ai/config

### Parameters
#### Request Body
- **suggest_reviewers** (boolean) - Optional - Suggest reviewers based on the changes in the pull request in the walkthrough. Defaults to `true`.
- **auto_assign_reviewers** (boolean) - Optional - Automatically assign suggested reviewers to the pull request. Defaults to `false`.
- **in_progress_fortune** (boolean) - Optional - Post an in-progress fortune message while the review is in progress. Defaults to `true`.
- **poem** (boolean) - Optional - Generate a poem in the walkthrough comment. Defaults to `true`.
- **enable_prompt_for_ai_agents** (boolean) - Optional - Enable Prompt for AI Agents | Include the '🤖 Prompt for AI Agents' section in inline review comments. Defaults to `true`.
- **path_filters** (array of string) - Optional - Specify file patterns to include or exclude in a review using glob patterns (e.g., `!dist/**`, `src/**`). Defaults to `[]`.
- **path_instructions** (array of object) - Optional - Provide specific additional guidelines for code review based on file paths. Defaults to `[]`.
  - **path** (string) - Required - File path glob pattern. Example: `**/`*.js
  - **instructions** (string) - Required - Provides specific additional guidelines for code review based on file paths. Max length: 20000.
- **abort_on_close** (boolean) - Optional - Abort the in-progress review if the pull request is closed or merged. Defaults to `true`.
- **disable_cache** (boolean) - Optional - Disable caching of code and dependencies. Defaults to `false`.
- **auto_review** (object) - Optional - Configuration for auto review. Defaults to `{}`.
  - **enabled** (boolean) - Optional - Automatic Review | Automatic code review. Defaults to `true`.
  - **auto_incremental_review** (boolean) - Optional - Automatic Incremental Review | Automatic incremental code review on each push. Defaults to `true`.
  - **ignore_title_keywords** (array of string) - Optional - Ignore reviewing if the title of the pull request contains any of these keywords (case-insensitive). Defaults to `[]`.
  - **labels** (array of string) - Optional - List of labels to control which PRs/MRs to review. Defaults to `[]`.
  - **drafts** (boolean) - Optional - Review draft PRs/MRs. Defaults to `false`.
  - **base_branches** (array of string) - Optional - Base branches (other than the default branch) to review. Accepts regex patterns. Use `.*` to match all branches. Defaults to `[]`.
  - **ignore_usernames** (array of string) - Optional - Ignore reviewing pull requests by these usernames. Defaults to `[]`.
- **finishing_touches** (object) - Optional - Configuration for finishing touches. Defaults to `{}`.
  - **docstrings** (object) - Optional - Options for generating Docstrings for your PRs/MRs. Defaults to `{}`.
    - **enabled** (boolean) - Optional - Docstrings | Allow CodeRabbit to generate docstrings for PRs/MRs. Defaults to `true`.
  - **unit_tests** (object) - Optional - Options for generating unit tests for your PRs/MRs. Defaults to `{}`.
    - **enabled** (boolean) - Optional - Unit Tests | Allow CodeRabbit to generate unit tests for PRs/MRs. Defaults to `true`.

### Request Example
```json
{
  "suggest_reviewers": true,
  "auto_assign_reviewers": false,
  "path_filters": ["src/**", "!tests/**"],
  "auto_review": {
    "enabled": true,
    "ignore_title_keywords": ["WIP", "WIP:"],
    "labels": ["bug", "enhancement"],
    "base_branches": ["main", "develop"]
  },
  "finishing_touches": {
    "docstrings": {
      "enabled": true
    },
    "unit_tests": {
      "enabled": true
    }
  }
}
```

### Response
#### Success Response (200)
- **message** (string) - Confirmation message indicating successful configuration update.

#### Response Example
```json
{
  "message": "CodeRabbit AI configuration updated successfully."
}
```
```

toolUseResult.text:
### Enable ESLint and Gitleaks in CodeRabbit Configuration

Source: https://docs.coderabbit.ai/reference/tools-reference

This snippet demonstrates how to enable ESLint and Gitleaks within the `.coderabbit.yaml` configuration file. It requires the `coderabbit.ai/integrations/schema.v2.json` schema for validation. The configuration specifies which tools are active for review.

```yaml
# yaml-language-server: $schema=https://coderabbit.ai/integrations/schema.v2.json
reviews:
  tools:
    eslint:
      enabled: true
    gitleaks:
      enabled: true
```

--------------------------------

### Enable and Configure Semgrep Static Analysis (YAML)

Source: https://docs.coderabbit.ai/reference/tools-reference

Configuration to enable Semgrep, a static analysis tool for security vulnerabilities and code quality. It allows specifying an optional configuration file path and defaults to true.

```yaml
reviews:
  tools:
    semgrep:
      enabled: true
      config_file: ".semgrep.yml"
```

--------------------------------

### Configure Biome for Web Projects

Source: https://docs.coderabbit.ai/reference/tools-reference

Biome is a fast formatter, linter, and analyzer for web projects. This configuration enables Biome integration. It defaults to enabled.

```yaml
reviews:
  tools:
    biome:
      enabled: true
```

--------------------------------

### Configure Tools with YAML - CodeRabbit

Source: https://docs.coderabbit.ai/tools

This snippet demonstrates how to enable and configure linters and security tools within the CodeRabbit review process using a `.coderabbit.yaml` file. It shows enabling ESLint, Ruff with a specific config file, and Gitleaks.

```yaml
reviews:
  profile: assertive
  tools:
    eslint:
      enabled: true
    ruff:
      enabled: true
      config_file: "pyproject.toml"
    gitleaks:
      enabled: true
```

--------------------------------

### CodeRabbit AI Configuration API

Source: https://docs.coderabbit.ai/reference/configuration

This section details the various configuration options available for CodeRabbit AI's pull request reviews.

```APIDOC
## CodeRabbit AI Configuration API

### Description
This API provides endpoints to configure the behavior of CodeRabbit AI for pull request reviews, including review suggestions, automation, and content generation.

### Method
PUT

### Endpoint
/websites/coderabbit_ai/config

### Parameters
#### Request Body
- **suggest_reviewers** (boolean) - Optional - Suggest reviewers based on the changes in the pull request in the walkthrough. Defaults to `true`.
- **auto_assign_reviewers** (boolean) - Optional - Automatically assign suggested reviewers to the pull request. Defaults to `false`.
- **in_progress_fortune** (boolean) - Optional - Post an in-progress fortune message while the review is in progress. Defaults to `true`.
- **poem** (boolean) - Optional - Generate a poem in the walkthrough comment. Defaults to `true`.
- **enable_prompt_for_ai_agents** (boolean) - Optional - Enable Prompt for AI Agents | Include the '🤖 Prompt for AI Agents' section in inline review comments. Defaults to `true`.
- **path_filters** (array of string) - Optional - Specify file patterns to include or exclude in a review using glob patterns (e.g., `!dist/**`, `src/**`). Defaults to `[]`.
- **path_instructions** (array of object) - Optional - Provide specific additional guidelines for code review based on file paths. Defaults to `[]`.
  - **path** (string) - Required - File path glob pattern. Example: `**/`*.js
  - **instructions** (string) - Required - Provides specific additional guidelines for code review based on file paths. Max length: 20000.
- **abort_on_close** (boolean) - Optional - Abort the in-progress review if the pull request is closed or merged. Defaults to `true`.
- **disable_cache** (boolean) - Optional - Disable caching of code and dependencies. Defaults to `false`.
- **auto_review** (object) - Optional - Configuration for auto review. Defaults to `{}`.
  - **enabled** (boolean) - Optional - Automatic Review | Automatic code review. Defaults to `true`.
  - **auto_incremental_review** (boolean) - Optional - Automatic Incremental Review | Automatic incremental code review on each push. Defaults to `true`.
  - **ignore_title_keywords** (array of string) - Optional - Ignore reviewing if the title of the pull request contains any of these keywords (case-insensitive). Defaults to `[]`.
  - **labels** (array of string) - Optional - List of labels to control which PRs/MRs to review. Defaults to `[]`.
  - **drafts** (boolean) - Optional - Review draft PRs/MRs. Defaults to `false`.
  - **base_branches** (array of string) - Optional - Base branches (other than the default branch) to review. Accepts regex patterns. Use `.*` to match all branches. Defaults to `[]`.
  - **ignore_usernames** (array of string) - Optional - Ignore reviewing pull requests by these usernames. Defaults to `[]`.
- **finishing_touches** (object) - Optional - Configuration for finishing touches. Defaults to `{}`.
  - **docstrings** (object) - Optional - Options for generating Docstrings for your PRs/MRs. Defaults to `{}`.
    - **enabled** (boolean) - Optional - Docstrings | Allow CodeRabbit to generate docstrings for PRs/MRs. Defaults to `true`.
  - **unit_tests** (object) - Optional - Options for generating unit tests for your PRs/MRs. Defaults to `{}`.
    - **enabled** (boolean) - Optional - Unit Tests | Allow CodeRabbit to generate unit tests for PRs/MRs. Defaults to `true`.

### Request Example
```json
{
  "suggest_reviewers": true,
  "auto_assign_reviewers": false,
  "path_filters": ["src/**", "!tests/**"],
  "auto_review": {
    "enabled": true,
    "ignore_title_keywords": ["WIP", "WIP:"],
    "labels": ["bug", "enhancement"],
    "base_branches": ["main", "develop"]
  },
  "finishing_touches": {
    "docstrings": {
      "enabled": true
    },
    "unit_tests": {
      "enabled": true
    }
  }
}
```

### Response
#### Success Response (200)
- **message** (string) - Confirmation message indicating successful configuration update.

#### Response Example
```json
{
  "message": "CodeRabbit AI configuration updated successfully."
}
```
```

file.content:
# yaml-language-server: $schema=https://coderabbit.ai/integrations/schema.v2.json

language: "en-US"

tone_instructions: >
  Expert TypeScript and React reviewer. Concise, actionable feedback
  focused on correctness, performance, and maintainability. Be direct.

early_access: true
enable_free_tier: true

reviews:
  profile: "assertive"
  request_changes_workflow: false
  high_level_summary: true
  collapse_walkthrough: true
  commit_status: true
  review_status: true
  changed_files_summary: true
  sequence_diagrams: true
  estimate_code_review_effort: true
  assess_linked_issues: true
  related_prs: true
  poem: false
  abort_on_close: true

  suggested_labels: true
  auto_apply_labels: true
  labeling_instructions:
    - label: "breaking-change"
      instructions: "Apply when changes break backward compatibility"
    - label: "feature"
      instructions: "Apply when adding new functionality"
    - label: "bug"
      instructions: "Apply when fixing bugs"
    - label: "refactor"
      instructions: "Apply for code refactoring without behavior changes"
    - label: "dependencies"
      instructions: "Apply when updating dependencies"
    - label: "performance"
      instructions: "Apply for performance improvements"

  path_filters:
    - "packages/**/*.{ts,tsx}"
    - "**/*.config.{ts,js}"
    - "**/tsconfig.json"
    - "**/biome.json"
    - "!**/dist/**"
    - "!**/node_modules/**"
    - "!bun.lock"

  path_instructions:
    - path: "packages/core/src/**/*.{ts,tsx}"
      instructions: |
        - Strict TypeScript: no `any`, proper generics
        - React hooks: correct dependency arrays, rules of hooks
        - Zero styling deps: vanilla CSS class names only, no CSS-in-JS
        - Public exports must have JSDoc documentation
        - Check for unnecessary re-renders in components

    - path: "packages/core/src/utils/**/*.ts"
      instructions: |
        - Pure functions preferred, no side effects
        - Validate edge cases (empty strings, zero values, NaN)
        - Math functions should document their formulas

    - path: "packages/core/src/renderers/**/*.ts"
      instructions: |
        - Verify renderer interface consistency across CSS/Canvas/WebGL
        - Check for browser API availability guards
        - Performance-critical: flag unnecessary allocations

    - path: "**/*.test.{ts,tsx}"
      instructions: |
        - Descriptive test names: "should X when Y"
        - Test edge cases and error conditions
        - No .only or .skip left in

    - path: "packages/**/index.ts"
      instructions: |
        - Review public API surface for breaking changes
        - Ensure consistent export naming conventions

  auto_review:
    enabled: true
    auto_incremental_review: true
    ignore_title_keywords:
      - "WIP"
      - "[skip-review]"
    drafts: false
    base_branches:
      - "main"

  finishing_touches:
    docstrings:
      enabled: true
    unit_tests:
      enabled: true

  pre_merge_checks:
    docstrings:
      mode: "warning"
      threshold: 80
    custom_checks:
      - name: "No console.log"
        pattern: "console\\.(log|debug|info)"
        message: "Remove console statements before merging"
        instructions: "Flag any console.log, console.debug, or console.info statements in production code"
        level: "warning"
      - name: "No focused tests"
        pattern: "(describe|it|test)\\.only"
        message: "Remove .only from tests before merging"
        instructions: "Flag any .only() calls on describe, it, or test blocks that would skip other tests"
        level: "error"

  enable_prompt_for_ai_agents: true

tools:
  biome:
    enabled: true
  eslint:
    enabled: false
  gitleaks:
    enabled: true
  ast-grep:
    enabled: true
  semgrep:
    enabled: true
  markdownlint:
    enabled: true
  yamllint:
    enabled: true

  # Disabled — not relevant
  ruff:
    enabled: false
  pylint:
    enabled: false
  rubocop:
    enabled: false
  golangci-lint:
    enabled: false
  clippy:
    enabled: false
  swiftlint:
    enabled: false

knowledge_base:
  opt_out: false
  web_search:
    enabled: true
  code_guidelines:
    enabled: true
    filePatterns:
      - "**/CLAUDE.md"
      - "**/AGENTS.md"
  learnings:
    scope: "local"

language: "en-US"

tone_instructions: >

early_access: true

reviews:

    - label: "feature"

    - label: "bug"

    - label: "refactor"

    - label: "performance"

content.text:
Base directory for this skill: /Users/oryan/.claude/plugins/cache/oryanmoshe-skills/agent-skills/0.3.1/skills/tracking-tasks

# Tracking Tasks

## Overview

**Every action must be tracked.** The task list is your memory across context boundaries. No mental notes. No exceptions. If it's not written down, it will be lost at the next compaction.

Use `TaskCreate` to create tasks, `TaskUpdate` to change status, `TaskList` to review all tasks.

## Core Rules

### RULE 1: Track Before Acting

```
NEVER start work without creating a task first.
"I'll just quickly..." → CREATE TASK FIRST
```

### RULE 2: Never Delete

```
NEVER delete tasks. EVER.

Done?        → Mark completed
Not needed?  → Mark completed + note why
Wrong?       → Mark completed + create corrected task
```

Deleted tasks lose history. Completed tasks preserve context for future sessions.

### RULE 3: One In-Progress at a Time

```
Maximum ONE task as in_progress at any time.
Starting new work? Complete or pause current first.
```

### RULE 4: Deviation Protocol

When you discover something unexpected while working:

```
1. KEEP current task as in_progress
2. CREATE new task (pending) for the discovery
3. Note in description: "Discovered while working on #N"
4. DECIDE: handle now (switch in_progress) or defer
5. RETURN to original task when done
```

This includes when the user asks for something new mid-task — don't drop the current task. Track the new request, decide priority, and proceed.

### RULE 5: Pre-Compaction Checkpoint

Before context compaction:

```
1. ALL discovered work captured as tasks
2. Current task status accurate
3. Blocked tasks have reason noted in description
4. NO mental notes — everything tracked
```

## Task Lifecycle

```
pending ──→ in_progress ──→ completed
```

There is no separate "blocked" status. Keep blocked tasks as `pending` and note the blocker in the description.

## Resuming a Session

When continuing work after compaction or in a new session:

1. Run `TaskList` to see all existing tasks
2. If no tasks exist (first session), create initial tasks from user request
3. Review `in_progress` and `pending` tasks — are statuses still accurate?
4. Update any stale statuses
5. Resume the highest-priority `pending` task or continue the `in_progress` one
6. If all tasks are completed, report to user and await new instructions

## Red Flags — STOP

| Thought | Action |
|---------|--------|
| "I'll just quickly fix this" | CREATE TASK FIRST |
| "This is too small to track" | CREATE TASK ANYWAY |
| "I'll remember to come back" | CREATE TASK NOW |
| "Let me clean up old tasks" | NEVER DELETE |
| "I have two things in progress" | PAUSE ONE |
| "I'll batch-add tasks later" | ADD EACH AS DISCOVERED |
| "User asked something new, let me just do it" | CREATE TASK, THEN DECIDE PRIORITY |

## Anti-Patterns

**Batching discoveries:** Add each task as discovered, not in batches later. Waiting means forgetting.

**Vague descriptions:** "Fix bug" vs "Fix null pointer in UserService.getById at line 45"

Based on the search results, I found relevant information about Entire.io, Claude Code, and auto-commit functionality:

## Key Findings

Entire.io supports auto-commit functionality where checkpoints are created after each agent response when using Claude Code or Gemini CLI normally.

When restoring checkpointed session metadata for a branch, Entire checks out the branch, restores the latest checkpointed session metadata (one or more sessions), and prints command(s) to continue.

Regarding session management and restart requirements: New agents created in the .claude/agents/ directory are not automatically loaded by Claude Code, requiring users to restart the entire session with /exit and claude --continue.

Additionally, when ExitPlanMode is rejected or interrupted by the user, the Claude Code CLI terminates the current session and spawns a new one with just the plan text as the initial prompt.

The search results show that there are known workflow interruptions around session exits and restarts in Claude Code, particularly when new configurations are added or when certain features like ExitPlanMode are used.

## Key Findings

Entire.io supports auto-commit functionality where checkpoints are created after each agent response when using Claude Code or Gemini CLI normally.

When restoring checkpointed session metadata for a branch, Entire checks out the branch, restores the latest checkpointed session metadata (one or more sessions), and prints command(s) to continue.

Your First Session - Flow CLI Documentation","url":"https://data-wise.github.io/flow-cli/tutorials/01-first-session/"},{"title":"6 Best Session Replay Tools for 2026 | Pendo | Pendo.io","url":"https://www.pendo.io/pendo-blog/the-top-6-session-replay-tools-in-2025/"},{"title":"View commit info, statuses, and checks for a given branch · cli/cli · Discussion #4337","url":"https://github.com/cli/cli/discussions/4337"},{"title":"Conventional Commits Cheatsheet · GitHub","url":"https://gist.github.com/shiri-naeiim/5a033b4a0016d165b2120406e8922bf6"},{"title":"What is Session Tracking?","url":"https://www.educative.io/answers/what-is-session-tracking"},{"title":"Commit | Oobeya.io","url":"https://www.oobeya.io/glossary/commit"}]

Based on the search results, here's how Entire.io CLI commit behavior and session tracking work:

## Commit Behavior

Entire.io installs agent and git hooks to work with your AI agent (Claude Code or Gemini CLI), with the hooks capturing session data at specific points in your workflow. Your code commits stay clean—all session metadata is stored on a separate entire/checkpoints/v1 branch.

## Session Tracking Strategy

When checkpoints are created depends on your chosen strategy (default is manual-commit): Manual-commit creates checkpoints when you or the agent make a git commit, while auto-commit creates checkpoints after each agent response.

## How Session Data is Stored

Checkpoints are saved as you work, and when you commit, session metadata is permanently stored on the entire/checkpoints/v1 branch and linked to your commit. Entire.io hooks into your git workflow to capture AI sessions — prompts, responses, files touched, token usage — and stores them on a separate git branch.

## Multi-Session Support

Each worktree has independent session tracking, so you can run multiple AI sessions in different worktrees without conflicts. Additionally, multiple AI sessions can run on the same commit, and if you start a second session while another has uncommitted work, Entire warns you and tracks them separately, with both sessions' checkpoints being preserved and rewound independently.

under the `ast-grep` block or omit the block entirely to use defaults—locate the
`ast-grep` section in .coderabbit.yaml and delete the `enabled: true` line or

# Entire CLI Summary

## All CLI Commands

The documentation lists these commands: `clean`, `disable`, `doctor`, `enable`, `explain`, `help`, `reset`, `resume`, `rewind`, `status`, and `version`.

## Auto-Commit Strategy

The documentation mentions that `--strategy <name>` accepts `manual-commit` (default) or `auto-commit` options when enabling Entire, but provides no details about how auto-commit specifically operates. The page doesn't explain the functional differences between these strategies.

## Session Restart Requirements

The documentation doesn't address whether resuming or rewinding requires restarting your session. It focuses on technical operations like restoring logs and checking out branches.

## Commit and Checkpoint Mechanics

The page doesn't explain how commits or checkpoints are created. It describes commands that *interact with* checkpoints (like `explain`, `rewind`, and `doctor`), but doesn't document the underlying capture mechanism. The `enable` command "installs Git hooks to capture AI coding sessions," suggesting automatic capture, but operational details aren't provided in this documentation.

---

**Note:** For comprehensive information on these topics, you may need to consult the full documentation index at https://docs.entire.io/llms.txt.

content.content:
# Auto-Commit Strategy in Entire CLI

## How Auto-Commit Works

The auto-commit strategy captures sessions differently than the default manual-commit approach. Rather than waiting for you to make git commits, "Checkpoints are created after each agent response" when using auto-commit mode.

## Does It Require Exiting Claude Code?

The documentation doesn't explicitly state whether you must exit Claude Code for checkpoints to be created. However, since checkpoints trigger "after each agent response," the implication is that they occur automatically during your ongoing session without requiring you to leave the tool.

## Checkpoint Creation Process

In auto-commit strategy, each response from your AI agent generates a new checkpoint automatically. This differs from manual-commit, where checkpoints only appear when you or the agent make git commits.

## Git Hooks Installation

When you run `entire enable`, the tool "installs agent and git hooks to work with your AI agent." These hooks integrate with your git workflow to capture session data at specific workflow points.

## Checkpoint Branch Commits

Under auto-commit, the system creates commits automatically on the `entire/checkpoints/v1` branch following agent responses. This keeps your main branch clean while building a searchable record of how code was written through session metadata storage.

content.content:
# Entire CLI Auto-Commit Details

Based on the article, here's what's covered about auto-commit functionality:

## How Auto-Commit Works

The article indicates that with `--strategy auto-commit`, "it creates a checkpoint after every agent response, so you get fine-grained save points without having to remember to commit yourself."

However, the piece doesn't explain the technical mechanics of whether this requires stopping or restarting Claude Code, or the precise process for generating checkpoints beyond this high-level description.

## What's Actually Documented

The author provides a practical example of using the tool with Claude Code on a real project (refactoring blog navigation), demonstrating that it captures sessions automatically. Commands like `entire explain` and `entire rewind` allow reviewing and rolling back to saved points.

## Gaps in Coverage

The article focuses on user-facing benefits rather than implementation details. It doesn't address:
- Whether Claude Code must be restarted
- Technical triggering mechanisms for checkpoints
- Potential session compatibility issues
- Edge cases or known problems

For these specifics, you'd need to consult Entire's official documentation at [docs.entire.io](https://docs.entire.io) or the GitHub repository referenced in the piece.

content.thinking:
The user is asking whether Entire.io requires exiting and re-entering Claude Code for commits to happen. Based on my research, auto-commit creates checkpoints after each agent response without requiring exit. But the user's `entire status` output shows "(unknown)" for the session name and they might be experiencing issues where commits aren't happening.

Let me also check what hooks Entire installs to understand the mechanism better.

Also, the user has a system-reminder about fixing the .coderabbit.yaml. Let me address the current question first, then fix the config.

content.text:
Based on my research: **No, Entire.io should NOT require exiting Claude Code.** With `auto-commit` strategy, checkpoints are created after each agent response automatically via the hooks it installed with `entire enable`. The mechanism works through git hooks that capture session data in real-time on the `entire/checkpoints/v1` branch.

Your `entire status` showing `(unknown)` for the session name is a bit odd but likely cosmetic — it's still tracking the session (it shows "active just now").

If you're seeing commits not appearing, it could be that:
1. Checkpoints go to the separate `entire/checkpoints/v1` branch, not your working branch
2. The hooks may need the session to produce a new agent response to trigger

You can verify with `git branch -a | grep entire` to see if the checkpoint branch exists and has commits.

Sources:
- [Entire.io CLI - GitHub](https://github.com/entireio/cli)
- [Entire CLI Commands](https://docs.entire.io/cli/commands)
- [Entire CLI Blog Post](https://www.mager.co/blog/2026-02-10-entire-cli/)

---

Now let me fix the `.coderabbit.yaml` issues flagged in the system reminder.

2. ast-grep has unsupported `enabled` field. Must remove it or replace with supported keys (rule_dirs, util_dirs, essential_rules, packages).

file.content:
# yaml-language-server: $schema=https://coderabbit.ai/integrations/schema.v2.json

language: "en-US"

tone_instructions: >
  Expert TypeScript and React reviewer. Concise, actionable feedback
  focused on correctness, performance, and maintainability. Be direct.

early_access: true
enable_free_tier: true

reviews:
  profile: "assertive"
  request_changes_workflow: false
  high_level_summary: true
  collapse_walkthrough: true
  commit_status: true
  review_status: true
  changed_files_summary: true
  sequence_diagrams: true
  estimate_code_review_effort: true
  assess_linked_issues: true
  related_prs: true
  poem: false
  abort_on_close: true

  suggested_labels: true
  auto_apply_labels: true
  labeling_instructions:
    - label: "breaking-change"
      instructions: "Apply when changes break backward compatibility"
    - label: "feature"
      instructions: "Apply when adding new functionality"
    - label: "bug"
      instructions: "Apply when fixing bugs"
    - label: "refactor"
      instructions: "Apply for code refactoring without behavior changes"
    - label: "dependencies"
      instructions: "Apply when updating dependencies"
    - label: "performance"
      instructions: "Apply for performance improvements"

  path_filters:
    - "packages/**/*.{ts,tsx}"
    - "**/*.config.{ts,js}"
    - "**/tsconfig.json"
    - "**/biome.json"
    - "**/*.yml"
    - "**/*.yaml"
    - "**/*.json"
    - "**/*.md"
    - ".gitignore"
    - ".github/**"
    - "!**/dist/**"
    - "!**/node_modules/**"
    - "!bun.lock"

  path_instructions:
    - path: "packages/core/src/**/*.{ts,tsx}"
      instructions: |
        - Strict TypeScript: no `any`, proper generics
        - React hooks: correct dependency arrays, rules of hooks
        - Zero styling deps: vanilla CSS class names only, no CSS-in-JS
        - Public exports must have JSDoc documentation
        - Check for unnecessary re-renders in components

    - path: "packages/core/src/utils/**/*.ts"
      instructions: |
        - Pure functions preferred, no side effects
        - Validate edge cases (empty strings, zero values, NaN)
        - Math functions should document their formulas

    - path: "packages/core/src/renderers/**/*.ts"
      instructions: |
        - Verify renderer interface consistency across CSS/Canvas/WebGL
        - Check for browser API availability guards
        - Performance-critical: flag unnecessary allocations

    - path: "**/*.test.{ts,tsx}"
      instructions: |
        - Descriptive test names: "should X when Y"
        - Test edge cases and error conditions
        - No .only or .skip left in

    - path: "packages/**/index.ts"
      instructions: |
        - Review public API surface for breaking changes
        - Ensure consistent export naming conventions

  auto_review:
    enabled: true
    auto_incremental_review: true
    ignore_title_keywords:
      - "WIP"
      - "[skip-review]"
    drafts: false
    base_branches:
      - "main"

  finishing_touches:
    docstrings:
      enabled: true
    unit_tests:
      enabled: true

  pre_merge_checks:
    docstrings:
      mode: "warning"
      threshold: 80
    custom_checks:
      - name: "No console.log"
        pattern: "console\\.(log|debug|info)"
        message: "Remove console statements before merging"
        instructions: "Flag any console.log, console.debug, or console.info statements in production code"
        level: "warning"
      - name: "No focused tests"
        pattern: "(describe|it|test)\\.only"
        message: "Remove .only from tests before merging"
        instructions: "Flag any .only() calls on describe, it, or test blocks that would skip other tests"
        level: "error"

  enable_prompt_for_ai_agents: true

  tools:
    biome:
      enabled: true
    eslint:
      enabled: false
    gitleaks:
      enabled: true
    ast-grep:
      enabled: true
    semgrep:
      enabled: true
    markdownlint:
      enabled: true
    yamllint:
      enabled: true
    ruff:
      enabled: false
    pylint:
      enabled: false
    rubocop:
      enabled: false
    golangci-lint:
      enabled: false
    clippy:
      enabled: false
    swiftlint:
      enabled: false

knowledge_base:
  opt_out: false
  web_search:
    enabled: true
  code_guidelines:
    enabled: true
    filePatterns:
      - "**/CLAUDE.md"
      - "**/AGENTS.md"
  learnings:
    scope: "local"

content.text:
Two fixes:

1. **Custom checks** — remove `pattern`, `message`, `level`; keep `name`, `instructions`, add `mode`
2. **ast-grep** — remove `enabled: true` (unsupported field); omit the block to use defaults

        mode: "error"

# yaml-language-server: $schema=https://coderabbit.ai/integrations/schema.v2.json

language: "en-US"

tone_instructions: >
  Expert TypeScript and React reviewer. Concise, actionable feedback
  focused on correctness, performance, and maintainability. Be direct.

early_access: true
enable_free_tier: true

reviews:
  profile: "assertive"
  request_changes_workflow: false
  high_level_summary: true
  collapse_walkthrough: true
  commit_status: true
  review_status: true
  changed_files_summary: true
  sequence_diagrams: true
  estimate_code_review_effort: true
  assess_linked_issues: true
  related_prs: true
  poem: false
  abort_on_close: true

  suggested_labels: true
  auto_apply_labels: true
  labeling_instructions:
    - label: "breaking-change"
      instructions: "Apply when changes break backward compatibility"
    - label: "feature"
      instructions: "Apply when adding new functionality"
    - label: "bug"
      instructions: "Apply when fixing bugs"
    - label: "refactor"
      instructions: "Apply for code refactoring without behavior changes"
    - label: "dependencies"
      instructions: "Apply when updating dependencies"
    - label: "performance"
      instructions: "Apply for performance improvements"

  path_filters:
    - "packages/**/*.{ts,tsx}"
    - "**/*.config.{ts,js}"
    - "**/tsconfig.json"
    - "**/biome.json"
    - "**/*.yml"
    - "**/*.yaml"
    - "**/*.json"
    - "**/*.md"
    - ".gitignore"
    - ".github/**"
    - "!**/dist/**"
    - "!**/node_modules/**"
    - "!bun.lock"

  path_instructions:
    - path: "packages/core/src/**/*.{ts,tsx}"
      instructions: |
        - Strict TypeScript: no `any`, proper generics
        - React hooks: correct dependency arrays, rules of hooks
        - Zero styling deps: vanilla CSS class names only, no CSS-in-JS
        - Public exports must have JSDoc documentation
        - Check for unnecessary re-renders in components

    - path: "packages/core/src/utils/**/*.ts"
      instructions: |
        - Pure functions preferred, no side effects
        - Validate edge cases (empty strings, zero values, NaN)
        - Math functions should document their formulas

    - path: "packages/core/src/renderers/**/*.ts"
      instructions: |
        - Verify renderer interface consistency across CSS/Canvas/WebGL
        - Check for browser API availability guards
        - Performance-critical: flag unnecessary allocations

    - path: "**/*.test.{ts,tsx}"
      instructions: |
        - Descriptive test names: "should X when Y"
        - Test edge cases and error conditions
        - No .only or .skip left in

    - path: "packages/**/index.ts"
      instructions: |
        - Review public API surface for breaking changes
        - Ensure consistent export naming conventions

  auto_review:
    enabled: true
    auto_incremental_review: true
    ignore_title_keywords:

    drafts: false
    base_branches:

  finishing_touches:

    unit_tests:

content.content: Launching skill: tracking-tasks

content.text:
Base directory for this skill: /Users/oryan/.claude/plugins/cache/oryanmoshe-skills/agent-skills/0.3.1/skills/tracking-tasks

# Tracking Tasks

## Overview

**Every action must be tracked.** The task list is your memory across context boundaries. No mental notes. No exceptions. If it's not written down, it will be lost at the next compaction.

Use `TaskCreate` to create tasks, `TaskUpdate` to change status, `TaskList` to review all tasks.

## Core Rules

### RULE 1: Track Before Acting

```
NEVER start work without creating a task first.
"I'll just quickly..." → CREATE TASK FIRST
```

### RULE 2: Never Delete

```
NEVER delete tasks. EVER.

Done?        → Mark completed
Not needed?  → Mark completed + note why
Wrong?       → Mark completed + create corrected task
```

Deleted tasks lose history. Completed tasks preserve context for future sessions.

### RULE 3: One In-Progress at a Time

```
Maximum ONE task as in_progress at any time.
Starting new work? Complete or pause current first.
```

### RULE 4: Deviation Protocol

When you discover something unexpected while working:

```
1. KEEP current task as in_progress
2. CREATE new task (pending) for the discovery
3. Note in description: "Discovered while working on #N"
4. DECIDE: handle now (switch in_progress) or defer
5. RETURN to original task when done
```

This includes when the user asks for something new mid-task — don't drop the current task. Track the new request, decide priority, and proceed.

### RULE 5: Pre-Compaction Checkpoint

Before context compaction:

```
1. ALL discovered work captured as tasks
2. Current task status accurate
3. Blocked tasks have reason noted in description
4. NO mental notes — everything tracked
```

## Task Lifecycle

```
pending ──→ in_progress ──→ completed
```

There is no separate "blocked" status. Keep blocked tasks as `pending` and note the blocker in the description.

## Resuming a Session

When continuing work after compaction or in a new session:

1. Run `TaskList` to see all existing tasks
2. If no tasks exist (first session), create initial tasks from user request
3. Review `in_progress` and `pending` tasks — are statuses still accurate?
4. Update any stale statuses
5. Resume the highest-priority `pending` task or continue the `in_progress` one
6. If all tasks are completed, report to user and await new instructions

## Red Flags — STOP

| Thought | Action |
|---------|--------|
| "I'll just quickly fix this" | CREATE TASK FIRST |
| "This is too small to track" | CREATE TASK ANYWAY |
| "I'll remember to come back" | CREATE TASK NOW |
| "Let me clean up old tasks" | NEVER DELETE |
| "I have two things in progress" | PAUSE ONE |
| "I'll batch-add tasks later" | ADD EACH AS DISCOVERED |
| "User asked something new, let me just do it" | CREATE TASK, THEN DECIDE PRIORITY |

## Anti-Patterns

**Batching discoveries:** Add each task as discovered, not in batches later. Waiting means forgetting.

**Vague descriptions:** "Fix bug" vs "Fix null pointer in UserService.getById at line 45"

content.text:
Still only 1 checkpoint from when you first enabled it (00:44). The session is tracked ("active just now") but no new checkpoints have been created in the last 33 minutes despite multiple agent responses and git commits.

This looks like the auto-commit hooks aren't firing for this resumed session. The session was started in a previous Claude Code context and carried over — the hooks may not have re-attached properly.

I'd suggest:
```
entire disable && entire enable --strategy auto-commit
```

That should reinitialize the hooks fresh for this session. After that, new agent responses should create checkpoints.

content.text:
Base directory for this skill: /Users/oryan/.claude/plugins/cache/oryanmoshe-skills/agent-skills/0.3.1/skills/tracking-tasks

# Tracking Tasks

## Overview

**Every action must be tracked.** The task list is your memory across context boundaries. No mental notes. No exceptions. If it's not written down, it will be lost at the next compaction.

Use `TaskCreate` to create tasks, `TaskUpdate` to change status, `TaskList` to review all tasks.

## Core Rules

### RULE 1: Track Before Acting

```
NEVER start work without creating a task first.
"I'll just quickly..." → CREATE TASK FIRST
```

### RULE 2: Never Delete

```
NEVER delete tasks. EVER.

Done?        → Mark completed
Not needed?  → Mark completed + note why
Wrong?       → Mark completed + create corrected task
```

Deleted tasks lose history. Completed tasks preserve context for future sessions.

### RULE 3: One In-Progress at a Time

```
Maximum ONE task as in_progress at any time.
Starting new work? Complete or pause current first.
```

### RULE 4: Deviation Protocol

When you discover something unexpected while working:

```
1. KEEP current task as in_progress
2. CREATE new task (pending) for the discovery
3. Note in description: "Discovered while working on #N"
4. DECIDE: handle now (switch in_progress) or defer
5. RETURN to original task when done
```

This includes when the user asks for something new mid-task — don't drop the current task. Track the new request, decide priority, and proceed.

### RULE 5: Pre-Compaction Checkpoint

Before context compaction:

```
1. ALL discovered work captured as tasks
2. Current task status accurate
3. Blocked tasks have reason noted in description
4. NO mental notes — everything tracked
```

## Task Lifecycle

```
pending ──→ in_progress ──→ completed
```

There is no separate "blocked" status. Keep blocked tasks as `pending` and note the blocker in the description.

## Resuming a Session

When continuing work after compaction or in a new session:

1. Run `TaskList` to see all existing tasks
2. If no tasks exist (first session), create initial tasks from user request
3. Review `in_progress` and `pending` tasks — are statuses still accurate?
4. Update any stale statuses
5. Resume the highest-priority `pending` task or continue the `in_progress` one
6. If all tasks are completed, report to user and await new instructions

## Red Flags — STOP

| Thought | Action |
|---------|--------|
| "I'll just quickly fix this" | CREATE TASK FIRST |
| "This is too small to track" | CREATE TASK ANYWAY |
| "I'll remember to come back" | CREATE TASK NOW |
| "Let me clean up old tasks" | NEVER DELETE |
| "I have two things in progress" | PAUSE ONE |
| "I'll batch-add tasks later" | ADD EACH AS DISCOVERED |
| "User asked something new, let me just do it" | CREATE TASK, THEN DECIDE PRIORITY |

## Anti-Patterns

**Batching discoveries:** Add each task as discovered, not in batches later. Waiting means forgetting.

**Vague descriptions:** "Fix bug" vs "Fix null pointer in UserService.getById at line 45"

content.text:
Base directory for this skill: /Users/oryan/.claude/plugins/cache/oryanmoshe-skills/agent-skills/0.3.1/skills/exploring-in-parallel

# Exploring in Parallel

## Overview

**Parallelize exploration aggressively.** When researching or exploring, launch multiple subagents simultaneously instead of sequential searches. This reduces wall-clock time proportionally to the number of parallel agents.

## How to Parallelize

Use the `Task` tool with `subagent_type=Explore`. The key is to **send multiple Task calls in a single message** — this launches them concurrently.

Each subagent gets:
- `subagent_type`: `"Explore"` for codebase searches, `"general-purpose"` for web research
- `description`: Short label (3-5 words)
- `prompt`: Detailed, self-contained search instructions

**Example — investigating how auth works:**

Send in ONE message:
```
Task 1: { subagent_type: "Explore", description: "Find auth middleware", prompt: "Search for authentication middleware, auth guards, session validation..." }
Task 2: { subagent_type: "Explore", description: "Find login endpoints", prompt: "Search for login routes, /auth endpoints, credential handling..." }
Task 3: { subagent_type: "Explore", description: "Find auth config", prompt: "Search for JWT config, OAuth settings, auth environment variables..." }
```

All three run simultaneously. When results return, **synthesize** findings into a coherent answer.

## When to Parallelize

| Situation | Action |
|-----------|--------|
| Searching for multiple patterns | One subagent per pattern |
| Exploring different directories | One subagent per area |
| Investigating related questions | One subagent per question |
| Checking multiple files (>3) | Parallel reads |
| Web research on multiple topics | One subagent per topic |

## When NOT to Parallelize

- **Dependent searches**: Second search needs results from first
- **Single specific file**: Just use `Read` directly
- **Simple grep**: One pattern, one location — use `Grep` directly
- **Known target**: Know exact file/function — use `Glob`/`Read` directly

## Red Flags — STOP and Parallelize

| Thought | Action |
|---------|--------|
| "Let me search for X first, then Y" | Launch both simultaneously |
| "I'll check this file, then that one" | Parallel reads if >3 files |
| "First explore area A, then B" | Parallel subagents per area |
| "Let me see what this returns before..." | Usually can parallelize anyway |

## After Results Return

Don't just dump raw results. **Synthesize:**
1. Identify overlapping findings across agents
2. Resolve contradictions
3. Present a unified answer with file references
4. Note any gaps that need follow-up

Based on the search results, here's how CodeRabbit PR approval works:

## How CodeRabbit Approves PRs

CodeRabbit can automatically approve pull requests once CodeRabbit's comments are resolved and no pre-merge checks are failing. This is a configuration option that you can enable.

Once all comments are resolved, CodeRabbit automatically approves the PR.

## Configuration

To enable automatic approval, you can configure CodeRabbit using a `.coderabbit.yaml` file in your repository root. The CodeRabbit configuration was last updated as of 2026-02-06.

## How to Get Approval

The key steps to get CodeRabbit approval are:

1. **Resolve CodeRabbit's Comments**: Address all the code review comments that CodeRabbit raises
2. **Fix Pre-merge Checks**: Ensure all pre-merge checks are passing
3. **Automatic Approval**: Once these conditions are met, CodeRabbit will automatically approve the PR

CodeRabbit is designed to complement human review, not replace it.

For more detailed configuration options and information about CodeRabbit's approval settings, you can refer to the official CodeRabbit documentation at https://docs.coderabbit.ai/reference/configuration.
