I've performed the web search for your query about CSS animations, gradient orb/blob drift effects, and modern best practices. Here's a summary of the key findings:

## Modern CSS Animation Techniques (2025-2026)

The CSS @property rule is a game-changer that lets developers define custom CSS properties and tell the browser what type of value they hold, like a <color> or an <angle>, making them directly animatable. This innovation, which is gaining broader support around 2024-2025, aligns perfectly with modern animation best practices, enabling smooth transitions without needing any JavaScript.

## Gradient Animations & Drift Effects

You could layer a slow, drifting aurora gradient over a faster, shimmering noise texture for a really unique feel. This approach lets you combine different speeds, directions, and styles of animation on a single element, resulting in truly unique and dynamic visual effects that stand out.

Animating a linear-gradient's background position creates a gentle, flowing stripe effect through methods that are lightweight and won't impact your site's performance.

## Blob & Orb Effects

Animated mesh gradients feature floating color blobs in teal, purple, blue and pink that drift and blend together, with multiple gradient blobs that orbit, rotate, and pulse at different speeds, all blending together with hard-light mix-blend-mode.

## Industry Trends & Tools

A 2025 analysis showed that over 60% of web designers and front-end developers regularly use specialized gradient tools, which are credited with slashing design time by an average of 30% compared to hand-coding from scratch.

## Performance Best Practices

Moving background-position on large elements increases paint cost, so keep animated areas small, limit the number of layers, and avoid huge background-size values.

The search results reference examples from Stripe and other design-forward companies as inspiration sources for gradient implementations.

Links: [{"title":"Motion — JavaScript & React animation library","url":"https://motion.dev/"},{"title":"Framer Motion React Animations | Refine","url":"https://refine.dev/blog/framer-motion/"},{"title":"Motion for React — Install & first React animation | Motion","url":"https://motion.dev/docs/react"},{"title":"react-spring","url":"https://react-spring.dev/"},{"title":"React <motion /> component | Motion","url":"https://motion.dev/docs/react-motion-component"},{"title":"Beyond Eye Candy: Top 7 React Animation Libraries for Real-World Apps in 2026 | Syncfusion Blogs","url":"https://www.syncfusion.com/blogs/post/top-react-animation-libraries"},{"title":"React Spring or Framer Motion: Which is Better?","url":"https://www.angularminds.com/blog/react-spring-or-framer-motion"},{"title":"React Spring vs. Framer Motion: Choosing the Right Animation","url":"https://www.dhiwise.com/post/react-spring-vs-framer-motion-a-detailed-guide-to-react"},{"title":"framer-motion - npm","url":"https://www.npmjs.com/package/framer-motion"},{"title":"GitHub - motiondivision/motion: A modern animation library for React and JavaScript","url":"https://github.com/motiondivision/motion"}]

Here's what I found about React animation library API design patterns, specifically for Framer Motion and React Spring:

## Key Libraries & Design Patterns

### Motion (formerly Framer Motion)

The `<motion />` component is the core API in Motion for React, providing a DOM element supercharged with animation capabilities. Motion's declarative API feels like a natural extension of React.

Key design patterns include:
- Variants, stagger and timelines make it easy to precisely orchestrate animations.
- Animate x, y, rotateZ etc independently, without wrapper elements.
- Motion's pick-up-and-play API is easy to start and fun to master.

### React Spring

React Spring provides great API with first-class support for hooks, performs well without triggering re-renders, and works cross-platform. Use imperative API methods to run animations without updating state, allowing you to respond to events without the React rendering overhead to achieve smooth, fluid animation.

## API Design Philosophy Comparison

**Framer Motion** emphasizes: Simplicity with a straightforward API, intuitiveness using common language and concepts, power despite its simplicity, and flexibility handling everything from simple to complex choreographies.

**React Spring** excels in: Spring-physics-based animations, offering a flexible and powerful approach to creating smooth animations. The API might have a steeper learning curve for developers unfamiliar with spring physics, but it offers greater control once mastered.

## DX Considerations (2025-2026)

Motion has more than 30.6k GitHub stars and 8.1 million weekly NPM downloads. Motion Studio provides visual and AI animation editing directly inside your code editor, with tools like the Codex, CSS spring generation, and CSS and Motion bezier editors.

Both libraries continue to be widely adopted in production applications, with Motion focusing on ease-of-use and developer experience through visual tooling, while React Spring emphasizes performance and physics-based control.

Based on my web search results, here's a comprehensive overview of npm library publishing best practices for 2026:

## ESM/CJS Dual Publishing

Publishing JavaScript packages that are compatible with both ECMAScript Modules (ESM) and CommonJS (CJS) is a critical skill for developers who aim to integrate wide-ranging libraries. Best practices include investigating the use of the main and module fields in package.json to differentiate entry points, and clarifying the purpose of the exports field, which is essential for controlling module resolution.

Node.js v22 and v23 introduced native support for CommonJS modules to require ESM modules, which is starting to relieve some of the complexity around dual publishing. Many package authors are still likely going to manage dual publishing of ESM and CJS packages for a while to maintain compatibility.

Once your package is published, you can verify if it follows best practices using publint.dev, which will also give you suggestions for improvements.

## Tree Shaking Optimization

Tree-shaking is supported by modern bundlers like Webpack, Rollup, and ESBuild, but it's only fully effective in production mode and with ESM. Some bundlers (like Webpack) require setting "sideEffects": false in package.json to eliminate code safely.

Tree-shaking eliminates code that's never used — like unused utility functions or unused exports from libraries. As a package author, you can provide a version of your package that contains ES2015 modules, while the rest has been transpiled to ES5, and it's important to set "sideEffects": false as after that webpack knows it's safe to tree shake the package.

## Peer Dependencies

You list a package under devDependencies in addition to peerDependencies so that your library can work properly during local development and testing, while still leaving it up to the consumer to install that package in their app. For example, with React: devDependencies lets you use React to develop and test your components, while peerDependencies tells the consumer to provide React. Each package must declare its own peer dependencies; they do not automatically carry over: peer dependencies do not inherit automatically, so packA and packB must declare React as a peerDependency.

## Provenance & Security

You can generate provenance statements for the packages you publish, which allows you to publicly establish where a package was built and who published a package, increasing supply-chain security for your packages.

Trusted publishing allows you to publish npm packages directly from your CI/CD workflows using OpenID Connect (OIDC) authentication, eliminating the need for long-lived npm tokens. This feature implements the trusted publishers industry standard specified by the Open Source Security Foundation (OpenSSF). Starting in October, NPM introduced a fundamental shift: all newly created write-enabled granular access tokens now come with a default expiration of just seven days, with a maximum lifespan of 90 days.

Provenance statements are created automatically when Trusted Publishing is enabled. However, only 26 (12.6%) of the 205 packages with public GitHub repositories that directly publish to npm have enabled provenance, indicating that adoption of this security feature remains limited.

Based on the search results, here's what I found about CSS @property, gradient animations, and custom properties in 2025:

## CSS @property for Animating Gradients

The CSS @property rule is a modern feature that lets developers define custom CSS properties and tell the browser what type of value they hold, like a <color> or an <angle>, making them directly animatable.

### The Problem It Solves

Gradient animations have historically presented challenges because browsers couldn't interpolate between different gradient values smoothly, forcing developers to use workarounds or JavaScript solutions that often resulted in choppy visual experiences.

### How It Works

To animate a gradient, you create a custom CSS property using the @property directive, which are type-safe, and the browser, based on their type, understands how to smoothly transition them. @property makes interpolation work by telling CSS what kind of unit is stored in the custom property—by specifying "<angle>", CSS knows how to interpolate changed values in animation, which means the animations can be smooth.

### Browser Support

Chrome and Edge currently support the @property API, with Safari following suit in recent versions, and Firefox support is expected to arrive within the year.

### Current Adoption (2025)

This innovation, which is gaining broader support around 2024-2025, aligns perfectly with modern animation best practices, enabling smooth transitions without needing any JavaScript.

The technique allows developers to create sophisticated gradient animations—including blob-like effects—using pure CSS without complex workarounds or JavaScript.

I've found information about Canvas 2D performance optimization techniques related to blur filters, metaballs, and compositing. Here's a summary of the key findings:

## Canvas 2D Metaball and Blur Performance

Metaballs are created using a basic concept of radial gradients with an alpha threshold—any pixel with alpha below the threshold is set to 0, and the metaball effect is achieved when gradients overlap and their alpha values add together above the threshold.

## Blur Filter Performance Issues

Gaussian blur algorithms in canvas filters are slow compared to other implementations and force the canvas to use software rendering. A workaround involves using WebGL shaders that implement Gaussian blur instead of relying on native canvas filter implementations.

## Performance Optimization Techniques

Several optimization strategies exist for Canvas 2D:

1. **Offscreen Canvas Rendering**: If you're repeating the same drawing operations on each animation frame, you can offload them to an offscreen canvas and then render the offscreen image to your primary canvas as often as needed.

2. **Layered Canvases**: You can use canvases layered on top of one another, and by using transparency in the foreground canvas, you can rely on the GPU to composite the alphas together at render time.

3. **Efficient Shadow/Blur Usage**: Blur operations in HTML5 canvas can be very expensive, so they should be used judiciously.

For real-time video blurring specifically, one technique involves drawing edge pixels and the video itself onto an offscreen canvas before finally drawing to the blurred canvas.

Based on the search results, here's what I found about Stripe's gradient mesh animation implementation:

## Implementation Overview

Many companies, including Stripe, are using a lightweight WebGL package for the gradient effect, rather than CSS-based animations. This small, 10kb file — around 800 lines of code — can create such beautiful gradient animations with minimal performance impact.

## Why Not CSS?

Animating gradients with CSS can consume a lot of RAM and CPU because it relies on high-frequency repaints and compositing to render each frame of the gradient animation. This process is intensive, especially for complex gradients or multiple elements, as the CPU handles the calculations.

## Technical Implementation

The code creates a WebGL context on a canvas element, defines shaders (vertex and fragment) for rendering, and uses a series of classes to manage mesh geometry, materials, and animation states. The MiniGl class handles WebGL initialization, shader compilation, and rendering. The gradient animation uses noise functions and other WebGL techniques to create smooth, dynamic gradient effects without the performance overhead of traditional methods.

## Advanced Features

GPU acceleration handles all heavy lifting through GLSL fragment shaders, and 3-layer Simplex noise is optimized for 60 FPS on mobile and desktop.

The implementation is based on reverse-engineering Stripe's approach, with publicly available examples and generators (like whatamesh.vercel.app) that allow developers to create their own gradient animations using the same WebGL-based technique.

I've completed the web search for your query about Starlight Astro documentation React component library interactive playground. Here are the key findings:

## Overview

Starlight is a documentation website framework for Astro. It's a full-featured documentation theme built on top of the Astro framework.

## Components and Integration

Starlight provides built-in components for common documentation use cases, available from the @astrojs/starlight/components package in MDX files and from the Starlight Markdoc preset in Markdoc files. Starlight ships as a framework-agnostic, complete docs solution that can be extended with React, Vue, Svelte, Solid, and more.

## Interactive Playgrounds

While the search results mention interactive components, there's an example of an interactive API Playground that only works if there's a user logged in. Developers can implement interactive playgrounds using Astro's features like Islands architecture, with Astro Islands allowing the addition of dynamic content to pages by injecting React components surgically to switch portions of page content on demand.

## Key Features

Starlight includes built-in cards, tabs, and more in the Components guide. For React integration specifically, the Astro React integration enables rendering and client-side hydration for React components.

The documentation and ecosystem around Starlight appear to be actively maintained and well-suited for building component-driven documentation sites.

I've completed the web search for your query about TypeScript/JavaScript package bundlers. Here's what I found:

## Key Bundlers

**tsup**: A fast and efficient, zero-configuration TypeScript bundler designed to streamline the process of compiling, optimizing, and outputting different module formats. tsup leverages esbuild under the hood for high-speed performance, supports modern ECMAScript modules and CommonJS(CJS), and provides built-in features like tree shaking, minification, and code splitting.

**pkgroll**: pkgroll is a JavaScript package bundler powered by Rollup that automatically builds your package from entry-points defined in package.json. pkgroll is zero-config and reads the entry-points declared in your package.json to determine how to bundle the package.

**unbuild**: unbuild uses rollup and is mentioned as a candidate for building NPM packages.

## Comparison

The search results highlight key differences: pkgroll is a thin abstraction over Rollup, while tsup is a thin abstraction over esbuild. As one package maintainer noted, tsup's limitations with supporting both ESM and CJS exports compelled them to develop pkgroll.

The results don't contain specific 2025-2026 updates, but the tools mentioned remain current options for bundling TypeScript libraries and npm packages.

I've completed the web search for React animation component library API design with a focus on declarative, imperative, composable, and hook-based patterns. Here are the key findings:

## API Design Patterns

Mature animation libraries support modern React apps with declarative APIs, hook-based integrations, and safe lifecycle handling.

**Declarative vs Imperative Approaches:**

- Framer Motion offers a declarative, component-based API that makes common transitions feel effortless: enter/exit animations, hover effects, page transitions, and layout shifts.

- GSAP integrates with React via refs and imperative APIs, making it less "React-y" but extremely powerful.

- React provides imperative APIs for patterns that are useful for building apps but hard to express in a declarative way.

## Hook-Based Design

React Spring has its API available in a pattern of plug-n-play React Hooks. Additionally, AutoAnimate uses the useAutoAnimate hook and attaches the ref property to the parent container for automatic list transitions.

React Spring is a physics-based animation library designed for fluid transitions and natural motion, using hooks like useSpring and useTransition to animate values over time.

## Composable Design

Because React is a declarative framework, declarative animation libraries pair well. Declarative and flexible APIs make it easy to define animations using hooks while keeping them highly customizable.

## Key Libraries

Popular options include Framer Motion (declarative, component-based), React Spring (physics-based with hooks), GSAP (imperative, timeline-driven), and AutoAnimate (low-setup, hook-based).

Links: [{"title":"Moving Mesh Gradient Background with Stripe Mesh Gradient WebGL Package | by Caden Chen | Bootcamp | Medium","url":"https://medium.com/design-bootcamp/moving-mesh-gradient-background-with-stripe-mesh-gradient-webgl-package-6dc1c69c4fa2"},{"title":"GitHub - exzenter/gradient-stripe: WebGL/JS animated mesh gradient inspired by Stripe’s design, with interactive controls and shader effects.","url":"https://github.com/exzenter/gradient-stripe"},{"title":"Stripe Mesh Gradient WebGL · GitHub","url":"https://gist.github.com/jordienr/64bcf75f8b08641f205bd6a1a0d4ce1d"},{"title":"gradient-stripe/README.md at main · exzenter/gradient-stripe","url":"https://github.com/exzenter/gradient-stripe/blob/main/README.md"},{"title":"How To create the Stripe Website Gradient Effect – Bram.us","url":"https://www.bram.us/2021/10/13/how-to-create-the-stripe-website-gradient-effect/"},{"title":"WebGL shader renderer for awesome animations","url":"https://colonel.shnyra.com/webgl-shader-renderer/"},{"title":"Phaser - A flowing WebGL gradient, deconstructed","url":"https://phaser.io/news/2025/05/a-flowing-webgl-gradient-deconstructed"},{"title":"A flowing WebGL gradient, deconstructed","url":"https://alexharri.com/blog/webgl-gradients"},{"title":"WebGL mesh gradient shaders from https://meshgradient.com, all credit to Burak Aslan https://www.producthunt.com/products/mesh-gradient · GitHub","url":"https://gist.github.com/lukepighetti/64464613a3170ce4f82dbe8a29b7b111"},{"title":"Moving Mesh Gradient Background with Stripe Mesh Gradient WebGL Package","url":"https://bytegoblin.io/blog/moving-mesh-gradient-background-with-stripe-mesh-gradient-webgl-package.mdx"}]

Based on the search results, here's what I found about WebGL mesh gradient implementation and Stripe's shader technique:

## Stripe's Mesh Gradient Implementation

Many companies, including Stripe, use a lightweight WebGL package for mesh gradient effects, with a small, 10kb file — around 800 lines of code — that can create such beautiful gradient animations with minimal performance impact.

## Core Shader Techniques

Stripe uses a minimalistic implementation of WebGL which they called minigl and a Gradient Class which is used to store animation properties and control the animation.

The shader implementation employs several sophisticated techniques:

1. **Noise-Based Animation**: The gradient animation uses noise functions and other WebGL techniques to create smooth, dynamic gradient effects without the performance overhead of traditional methods.

2. **Fractal Brownian Motion**: Instead of using simple noise, the shader employs Fractal Brownian Motion, which layers multiple octaves of Simplex noise, where each successive layer has a higher frequency (lacunarity) and lower amplitude (persistence).

3. **Coordinate Modulation**: To avoid the static look of pure noise, the coordinate system is modulated by a sinusoidal mesh, with sin() and cos() functions applied to the UV coordinates with time-based offsets, so the noise "warps" against itself.

4. **Advanced Color Blending**: Instead of a simple mix(), the shader implements professional blend modes (Multiply, Screen, Overlay, etc.) directly in the fragment shader, allowing colors to "interact" rather than just overlap.

5. **CSS Enhancement**: The WebGL canvas is a full rectangle, but its container is transformed using skewY(-12deg) and overflow: hidden, creating the signature sharp diagonal edges that define the Stripe design language.

## Performance Advantages

WebGL uses the GPU to handle animations, which is much more efficient for rendering and computing complex animations, with the GPU being designed for parallel processing, resulting in less RAM and CPU usage and smoother performance.

# Stripe Gradient Effect - Technical Implementation Summary

Based on the provided content, here's what's available regarding the technical setup:

## Architecture Overview

The implementation uses a **minimalist WebGL approach** called "minigl" combined with a dedicated Gradient class. The author notes: "Essentially all they are using is a minimalistic implementation of WebGL which they called minigl...and a Gradient Class which is used to store all of our animation properties and control the animation."

## Core Components

**Canvas Configuration:**
The canvas element uses CSS custom properties for color definition:
```
--gradientcolorzero: #6ec3f4;
--gradientcolorone: #3a3aff;
--gradientcolortwo: #ff61ab;
--gradientcolorthree: #E63946;
```

**Transform Properties:**
Key CSS variables control the visual effect:
- `--section-skew-Y: -12deg` (tilt angle)
- `--section-angle-sin: 0.212` (derived calculation for coverage)

**Text Blending:**
Three layered text elements use CSS blending modes:
- Base text (visible outside gradient)
- Blended layer with `mix-blend-mode: color-burn`
- Overlay with 0.2 opacity for readability

## Key Limitation

The author acknowledges incomplete reverse-engineering: "I am currently still trying to figure out the code, but until then here is the working example."

No shader code, detailed MiniGL class structure, or performance optimization specifics are provided in this content.

content.content:
# Technical Extraction: Color Banding Fixes and GLSL Techniques

## Core Noise Function

The article's primary technique employs **Interleaved Gradient Noise**, credited to Jorge Jimenez from his Call of Duty: Advanced Warfare presentation:

```glsl
float gradientNoise(in vec2 uv) {
    return fract(52.9829189 * fract(dot(uv, vec2(0.06711056, 0.00583715))));
}
```

This one-liner generates noise "halfway between dithered and random" patterns without texture sampling or multiple passes.

## Radial Gradient Implementation

The basic gradient rendering uses `mix()` with distance calculations:

```glsl
vec3 bgcolor = mix(insidecolor, outsidecolor, 
                   length(vec2(tex.x, tex.y * 0.5 + 1.0)));
```

For radial falloffs: `length(tex)` computes Euclidean distance from center.

## Banding Mitigation Strategy

Apply noise scaled to 8-bit precision while offsetting average brightness:

```glsl
bgcolor += (1.0 / 255.0) * gradientNoise(gl_FragCoord.xy) - (0.5 / 255.0);
```

The subtraction of 0.5/255.0 maintains original luminance by counteracting the noise's mean contribution.

## Critical Implementation Notes

- **Pixel-perfect rendering**: Must display at 1:1 screen pixel density; browser scaling reintroduces banding
- **6-bit panel interference**: Matching noise to panel bit-depth (dividing by 63) creates visible interference patterns—avoid this approach
- **No double-dithering**: Don't combine with panel-level dithering; results are counterproductive

## Alternative Professional Approaches

**Valve Software's technique** (Portal 2 era):
```hlsl
float3 vDither = dot(float2(171.0, 231.0), vScreenPos.xy + g_flTime).xxx;
vDither.rgb = frac(vDither.rgb / float3(103.0, 71.0, 97.0)) - 0.5;
return (vDither.rgb / 255.0) * 0.375;
```

Uses temporal animation for reduced visual artifacts.

**ReShade's Deband**: Detects flat regions via Weber ratio and standard deviation analysis, applying selective dithering only where needed.

**10-bit Deep Color**: Increases quantization steps from 256 to 1,024 per channel, virtually eliminating banding at higher computational cost.

## Shader Optimization

**Bufferless version** (OpenGL 3.3+) eliminates vertex buffer overhead:
- Uses `gl_VertexID` to generate fullscreen triangle in vertex shader
- Reduces CPU-GPU synchronization points

---

**Key takeaway**: The gradient noise technique provides compelling results with minimal performance cost—a 13-character function addresses what historically required texture memory or algorithmic complexity.

content.content:
# TypeScript ESM/CJS Publishing in 2025: Technical Summary

## Ecosystem Challenges

The JavaScript ecosystem remains fragmented regarding module publishing. Key pain points include:

- **Dual publishing complexity**: Projects must support both ESM and CommonJS to maintain broad compatibility
- **Configuration overhead**: Managing `package.json` exports, the `type` field, and multiple output formats requires explicit toolchain setup
- **Legacy Node.js support**: Not all environments have adopted Node.js v22+ with native CommonJS-to-ESM interoperability

## Recent Improvements

Two significant developments are reshaping the landscape:

1. **JSR.io**: A new registry emphasizing modern JavaScript with TypeScript support and native ESM distribution
2. **Node.js v22/v23**: Native CommonJS support for requiring ESM modules, previously requiring the `--experimental-require-module` flag

## Recommended Build Strategy

**tsup** emerges as the preferred bundler. The article describes it as "simple to use" for transpiling TypeScript to dual-format JavaScript outputs. Key configuration includes:

- Entry points for multiple distribution targets
- Output extensions: `.mjs` (ESM) and `.cjs` (CommonJS) for version compatibility
- TypeScript definition file generation

Sample configuration declares format outputs, destination directories, tree-shaking behavior, and target ES2022 standards.

## Package.json Setup

Essential fields include:

- `"type": "module"` declaration
- `exports` field with conditional imports/requires directing to appropriate `.mjs` or `.cjs` files
- Separate type definitions for each module format (`.d.ts` and `.d.cts`)

## Runtime Execution

**ts-node** with the `--loader ts-node/esm` flag enables direct TypeScript execution without pre-compilation, suitable for testing workflows.

## Scaffolding Solution

The `create-node-lib` template provides pre-configured projects with dual-publishing setup, coverage tools, and CI/CD workflows.

- **Index effect**: `duration *= (1 + index * 0.3)` — each orb 30% slower
- **Delay**: `index * -baseDuration * 0.25` — staggered negative start
- **Ellipse path**: 8-step with 45° diagonal points (cos45 = √1/2 ≈ 0.707)

| **Editor** | index.ts | Stubbed | 5% (version constant only) |
| **Examples** | basic/package.json | Minimal Scaffold | 0% (no source) |

---

## 7. Key Gaps & Issues

### High-Impact Gaps
1. **OrbScene context not implemented** — Child orbs can't inherit scene settings (background, grain, breathing, preset resolution). Components work in isolation but not as composed scene.
2. **Drift animation not wired** — Animation functions exist but `<Orb drift={true}>` doesn't apply animations.
3. **Wavy SVG filters not implemented** — `wavy={true}` prop accepted but no effect.
4. **Interactive hover effects not implemented** — `interactive={true}` prop accepted but no listeners/styles.
5. **Editor completely missing** — Only a stub. Needs 80+ hours of work (canvas, drag, color picker, sliders, logic).
6. **Canvas renderer not implemented** — Stub only.
7. **WebGL renderer not implemented** — Stub only.
8. **Examples have no source code** — Only package.json; no App.tsx, no index.html, no demo content.

### Medium-Impact Issues
1. **Preset resolution in OrbScene** — `preset="ocean"` prop ignored; would need context to pass preset points to children.
2. **Renderer selection** — Props accept `renderer="canvas"` but no switching logic; always CSS.
3. **Breathing (global animation intensity)** — Prop accepted but not passed to child orbs or used in duration calculations.
4. **Grain overlay injection** — `grain={0.35}` prop accepted but `<Grain>` component never auto-inserted; must be manually added.

### Minor Issues
1. No CSS class files for styling (project is "zero styling opinion" so this is intentional).
2. No error handling for invalid color hex strings.
3. No validation of 0-1 position bounds.
4. Placeholder `_` parameters in Orb/OrbScene (underscores signal unused, which is fine for TODOs).

---

## 8. What's Working Perfectly

1. **Color utilities** — Full HSL ↔ Hex conversion with tests
2. **Animation math** — Deterministic orbit generation with breathing/index scaling
3. **CSS rendering** — Radial gradients with blur + blend modes
4. **Grain overlay** — Canvas-based noise with resize handling
5. **Type system** — Comprehensive, strict TypeScript definitions
6. **Preset data** — 5 well-designed presets
7. **Build system** — Bun workspaces, ESM + CJS + types outputs
8. **Testing** — Bun test runner with coverage for critical utilities
9. **Linting** — Biome checks + Lefthook pre-commit hooks
10. **Git integration** — Gitmoji + conventional commits enforced

---

## 9. Recommended Next Steps (by priority)

1. **Wire drift animation into `<Orb>`** — Apply CSS keyframes from `generateOrbAnimation()` when `drift={true}`
2. **Implement OrbScene context** — Create React context to pass scene settings to child orbs; resolve presets
3. **Implement SVG filter waviness** — Use `feTurbulence` + `feDisplacementMap` when `wavy={true}`
4. **Add interactive hover effects** — Mouse listeners + transform/filter updates
5. **Scaffold examples/basic** — Create App.tsx with usage demos
6. **Implement Canvas renderer** — Full Canvas 2D implementation (medium effort)
7. **Build editor UI** — Canvas preview, draggable points, color picker, sliders (high effort)
8. **Implement WebGL renderer** — GLSL shaders + simplex noise (highest effort, best visuals)

---

## 10. Codebase Quality Assessment

| Criterion | Rating | Notes |
|-----------|--------|-------|
| **TypeScript Strictness** | A | Full strict mode, no `any`, excellent types |
| **Testing** | B+ | Good test coverage for utilities; no component tests |
| **Documentation** | A | CONTEXT.md, AGENTS.md, CLAUDE.md comprehensive |
| **Code Organization** | A | Clear file structure, separated concerns (components/renderers/utils/presets) |
| **Build/CI/CD** | A | Bun monorepo, GitHub Actions CI, Lefthook hooks |
| **Styling Approach** | A | "Zero opinion" vanilla CSS, no dependencies |
| **API Design** | A | Clean props interfaces, composable + preset modes |
| **Implementation Completeness** | C | Core ~60%, Editor ~5%, Advanced renderers 0% |

**Overall**: Excellent foundation with professional tooling and clear design. Core utilities fully implemented and tested. Main limitation is incomplete wiring of advanced features (drift, wavy, interactive, context, Canvas/WebGL renderers) and missing editor.

---

This audit is based on reading every source file in the project. All findings are current as of the repository state.

# OrbKit Codebase Complete Audit Report

## Executive Summary

OrbKit is a **composable, animated orb effects library for React** with multi-orb scene support, per-orb effects (blur, blend modes, waviness, drift animation), and optional visual editor. The project is a Bun monorepo using TypeScript strict mode with zero styling dependencies.

**Current Status**: Core library ~60% implemented; editor ~5% (stub); examples minimal.

---

### `/Users/oryan/dev/orbkit/packages/core/src/utils/animation.ts`
**Status**: Fully implemented
**Exports** (3 functions):

| Function | Input | Output | Purpose | Status |
|----------|-------|--------|---------|--------|
| `getOrbitParams(x, y, index, breathing)` | Position + index + breathing (0-100) | `{amplitudeX, amplitudeY, duration, delay}` | Deterministic orbit params from position | Fully implemented |
| `generateDriftKeyframes(ax, ay)` | Amplitudes X/Y | Array of 9 keyframe objects `{offset, transform}` | Elliptical path keyframes | Fully implemented |
| `generateDriftKeyframeCSS(name, ax, ay)` | Animation name + amplitudes | CSS @keyframes string | Readable CSS animation | Fully implemented |

**Algorithm Details**:
- **Position seeding**: `seed = x*1000 + y*7919` → deterministic per-position
- **Pseudo-random**: `Math.sin(seed) * 10000` modulo 1 → consistent values
- **Amplitude range**: MIN=2, MAX=10; scaled by breathing factor
- **Duration**: MIN=6s, MAX=40s; breathing adjusts inverse (more breathing = faster)
- **Index effect**: `duration *= (1 + index * 0.3)` — each orb 30% slower
- **Delay**: `index * -baseDuration * 0.25` — staggered negative start
- **Ellipse path**: 8-step with 45° diagonal points (cos45 = √1/2 ≈ 0.707)

**Testing**: Full test suite validating determinism, index scaling, breathing effects, keyframe structure.

| **Utils** | color.ts | Fully Implemented | 100% |
| | color.test.ts | Fully Implemented | 100% tests |
| | animation.ts | Fully Implemented | 100% |
| | animation.test.ts | Fully Implemented | 100% tests |
| **Renderers** | css-renderer.ts | Fully Implemented | 100% |
| | canvas-renderer.ts | Stubbed | 0% |
| | webgl-renderer.ts | Stubbed | 0% |
| **Presets** | index.ts | Fully Implemented | 100% (5 presets) |
| **Editor** | index.ts | Stubbed | 5% (version constant only) |
| **Examples** | basic/package.json | Minimal Scaffold | 0% (no source) |

---

## 7. Key Gaps & Issues

### High-Impact Gaps
1. **OrbScene context not implemented** — Child orbs can't inherit scene settings (background, grain, breathing, preset resolution). Components work in isolation but not as composed scene.
2. **Drift animation not wired** — Animation functions exist but `<Orb drift={true}>` doesn't apply animations.
3. **Wavy SVG filters not implemented** — `wavy={true}` prop accepted but no effect.
4. **Interactive hover effects not implemented** — `interactive={true}` prop accepted but no listeners/styles.
5. **Editor completely missing** — Only a stub. Needs 80+ hours of work (canvas, drag, color picker, sliders, logic).
6. **Canvas renderer not implemented** — Stub only.
7. **WebGL renderer not implemented** — Stub only.
8. **Examples have no source code** — Only package.json; no App.tsx, no index.html, no demo content.

### Medium-Impact Issues
1. **Preset resolution in OrbScene** — `preset="ocean"` prop ignored; would need context to pass preset points to children.
2. **Renderer selection** — Props accept `renderer="canvas"` but no switching logic; always CSS.
3. **Breathing (global animation intensity)** — Prop accepted but not passed to child orbs or used in duration calculations.
4. **Grain overlay injection** — `grain={0.35}` prop accepted but `<Grain>` component never auto-inserted; must be manually added.

### Minor Issues
1. No CSS class files for styling (project is "zero styling opinion" so this is intentional).
2. No error handling for invalid color hex strings.
3. No validation of 0-1 position bounds.
4. Placeholder `_` parameters in Orb/OrbScene (underscores signal unused, which is fine for TODOs).

---

## 8. What's Working Perfectly

1. **Color utilities** — Full HSL ↔ Hex conversion with tests
2. **Animation math** — Deterministic orbit generation with breathing/index scaling
3. **CSS rendering** — Radial gradients with blur + blend modes
4. **Grain overlay** — Canvas-based noise with resize handling
5. **Type system** — Comprehensive, strict TypeScript definitions
6. **Preset data** — 5 well-designed presets
7. **Build system** — Bun workspaces, ESM + CJS + types outputs
8. **Testing** — Bun test runner with coverage for critical utilities
9. **Linting** — Biome checks + Lefthook pre-commit hooks
10. **Git integration** — Gitmoji + conventional commits enforced

---

## 9. Recommended Next Steps (by priority)

1. **Wire drift animation into `<Orb>`** — Apply CSS keyframes from `generateOrbAnimation()` when `drift={true}`
2. **Implement OrbScene context** — Create React context to pass scene settings to child orbs; resolve presets
3. **Implement SVG filter waviness** — Use `feTurbulence` + `feDisplacementMap` when `wavy={true}`
4. **Add interactive hover effects** — Mouse listeners + transform/filter updates
5. **Scaffold examples/basic** — Create App.tsx with usage demos
6. **Implement Canvas renderer** — Full Canvas 2D implementation (medium effort)
7. **Build editor UI** — Canvas preview, draggable points, color picker, sliders (high effort)
8. **Implement WebGL renderer** — GLSL shaders + simplex noise (highest effort, best visuals)

---

## 10. Codebase Quality Assessment

| Criterion | Rating | Notes |
|-----------|--------|-------|
| **TypeScript Strictness** | A | Full strict mode, no `any`, excellent types |
| **Testing** | B+ | Good test coverage for utilities; no component tests |
| **Documentation** | A | CONTEXT.md, AGENTS.md, CLAUDE.md comprehensive |
| **Code Organization** | A | Clear file structure, separated concerns (components/renderers/utils/presets) |
| **Build/CI/CD** | A | Bun monorepo, GitHub Actions CI, Lefthook hooks |
| **Styling Approach** | A | "Zero opinion" vanilla CSS, no dependencies |
| **API Design** | A | Clean props interfaces, composable + preset modes |
| **Implementation Completeness** | C | Core ~60%, Editor ~5%, Advanced renderers 0% |

**Overall**: Excellent foundation with professional tooling and clear design. Core utilities fully implemented and tested. Main limitation is incomplete wiring of advanced features (drift, wavy, interactive, context, Canvas/WebGL renderers) and missing editor.

---

This audit is based on reading every source file in the project. All findings are current as of the repository state.

# Top React Animation Libraries for 2026 ## Overview The article identifies seven actively maintained animation libraries chosen for production stability, React compatibility, and real-world adoption rather than visual flashiness. ## The Seven Libraries ### 1. **Motion (Formerly Framer Motion)** - **Downloads:** 8.1M weekly npm; 30.6k GitHub stars - **API Pattern:** Declarative, component-based - **Core Approach:** Wraps elements in `` with `animate` and `transition` props - **Key Features:** - Variants and orchestration for reusable states - Built-in gesture support (drag, hover, tap, pan) - Automatic layout animations - `AnimatePresence` for mount/unmount transitions - Next.js optimization **Example:** ```javascript ``` ### 2. **react-spring** - **Downloads:** 1.5M weekly npm; 29k GitHub stars - **API Pattern:** Hook-based with physics simulation - **Core Approach:** Spring physics instead of fixed timing - **Key Features:** - `useSpring`, `useTrail`, `useTransition`, `useChain` hooks - Tension, friction, and mass parameters - Chain and orchestrate multiple animations - Cross-platform extensibility **Example:** ```javascript const props = useSpring({ from: { opacity: 0 }, to: { opacity: 1 }, config: { duration: 1500 } }); ``` ### 3. **GSAP (GreenSock Animation Platform)** - **Downloads:** 750k+ weekly npm; 23k+ GitHub stars - **API Pattern:** Imperative with timeline control - **Core Approach:** General-purpose JS engine adapted for React via `useGSAP` hook - **Key Features:** - Timeline sequencing and nesting - ScrollTrigger plugin for scroll-based animations - Extensive easing functions and plugins - ScrollTrigger scrubbing and pinning **Example:** ```javascript useGSAP(() => { gsap.to(".box", { x: 200, rotation: 360, duration: 2, repeat: -1, yoyo: true }); }); ``` ### 4. **AutoAnimate** - **Downloads:** 200k+ weekly npm; 13k+ GitHub stars - **API Pattern:** Hook-based with automatic detection - **Core Approach:** Detects DOM changes and applies transitions automatically - **Key Features:** - Automatic detection of list additions/removals/reordering - Zero dependencies, lightweight - Scoped application via refs - Configurable duration and easing **Example:** ```javascript const [parent] = useAutoAnimate();
    {items.map(item =>
  • {item}
    • )}
``` ### 5. **React Transition Group** - **Downloads:** 10M+ weekly npm; 10k+ GitHub stars - **API Pattern:** Lifecycle-focused wrapper components - **Core Approach:** Exposes mounting/unmounting phases without built-in animation - **Key Features:** - `CSSTransition` component for CSS-based effects - `mountOnEnter/unmountOnExit` for performance - Minimal overhead, relies on external animation tools - Accessibility-friendly design **Example:** ```javascript
Content
 ``` ### 6. **Lottie React** - **Downloads:** 800k+ weekly npm - **API Pattern:** Component-based for vector animations - **Core Approach:** Plays JSON animations exported from design tools - **Key Features:** - High-fidelity After Effects export rendering - Speed, direction, segment, and looping controls - Event callbacks for lifecycle events - Responsive and device-scalable **Example:** ```javascript ``` ### 7. **Anime.js with React** - **Downloads:** 150k+ weekly npm; 65k GitHub stars - **API Pattern:** Imperative with effect hooks - **Core Approach:** Lightweight JS engine integrated via `useRef` and `useEffect` - **Key Features:** - CSS, SVG, and JS object animation - Timeline and stagger functions - Extensive easing and custom functions - Scroll observer for interactive triggers **Example:** ```javascript const ref = useRef(null); useEffect(() => { anime({ targets: ref.current, translateX: 200, rotate: 360, duration: 2000 }); }, []); ``` ## Performance & Use Case Summary | Library | Best For | Complexity | Bundle Impact | |---------|----------|-----------|---| | Motion | Declarative UI transitions, gestures | Medium | Moderate | | react-spring | Physics-based, natural motion | Medium | Small | | GSAP | Complex sequences, scroll triggers | High | Moderate | | AutoAnimate | List/table transitions | Low | Very Small | | React Transition Group | Lightweight lifecycle control | Low | Minimal | | Lottie React | Vector/design tool animations | Low | Small | | Anime.js | Precise DOM/CSS control | Medium | Small | ## Selection Criteria for 2026 The article emphasizes libraries demonstrating sustained maintenance, React compatibility with hooks and server-side rendering, and widespread production adoption—avoiding tools with declining support or limited real-world usage.

content.content:
# Canvas 2D Performance Optimization Techniques

Based on the web.dev article, here are the key optimization strategies:

## Offscreen Rendering
"Pre-rendering means using a separate off-screen canvas (or canvases) on which to render temporary images, and then rendering the off-screen canvases back onto the visible one." This is particularly effective for expensive operations like text rendering. Ensure your temporary canvas "fits snugly around the image" to avoid performance losses from copying oversized canvases.

## Batch Operations
Rather than issuing multiple drawing commands separately, combine them into one operation. "When drawing a complex path, for example, it's better to put all of the points into the path, rather than rendering the segments separately."

## Minimize State Changes
Avoid frequently switching canvas properties like fill colors. Group operations by state instead—render all shapes of one color, then switch to another color and continue, rather than alternating colors with each shape.

## Differential Rendering
Instead of clearing and redrawing the entire canvas each frame, "Keep track of the drawn bounding box, and only clear that," rendering only what has changed.

## Layered Canvases
Use multiple absolutely positioned canvases for complex scenes. "By using transparency in the foreground canvas, we can rely on the GPU to composite the alphas together at render time," enabling separate update rates for different layers.

## Additional Tips
- Avoid `shadowBlur` operations (computationally expensive)
- Use integer coordinates instead of floating-point values
- Employ `requestAnimationFrame` for synchronized rendering
- Note: Mobile canvas performance remains significantly slower than desktop implementations

# npm Trusted Publishing Setup Guide

## Overview
Following supply chain attacks on npm, GitHub Actions workflows should migrate from long-lived tokens to trusted publishing with short-lived credentials and provenance attestations.

## Key Configuration Requirements

**Workflow Permissions:**
Add OIDC token generation capability:
```yaml
permissions:
  id-token: write
```

**npm Version:**
"Trusted publishing requires npm CLI version 11.5.1 or later." Update before publishing:
```yaml
- run: npm install -g npm@latest
```

**Provenance Flag:**
Despite documentation suggesting automatic generation, explicitly include:
```yaml
- run: npm publish --provenance
```

Alternatively, configure in `package.json`:
```json
{
  "publishConfig": {
    "provenance": true
  }
}
```

Or via environment variable:
```yaml
env:
  NPM_CONFIG_PROVENANCE: true
```

## Package Setup

**npm Registry Configuration:**
Access package-specific settings at `https://www.npmjs.com/package/${packageName}/access` rather than account-level settings. Register trusted publishers individually for each package.

**Repository Field:**
Ensure `package.json` matches registered repository details:
```json
{
  "repository": {
    "type": "git",
    "url": "git+https://github.com/${username}/${packageName}.git"
  }
}
```

## Benefits
This approach eliminates long-lived token vulnerabilities while generating cryptographic provenance attestations that document package origins and build conditions, enhancing ecosystem security.

content.content:
# Gradient Stripe WebGL Implementation

## Shader Architecture

The project uses **WebGL 1.0 with GLSL** to render an animated mesh gradient effect. The system employs a full-rectangle canvas positioned within a skewed container (`skewY(-12deg)` with `overflow: hidden`) to achieve the signature diagonal stripe aesthetic without complex geometry.

## Noise & Animation

**Fractal Brownian Motion (FBM)** forms the foundation. Rather than basic noise, the shader "layers multiple octaves of Simplex noise, where each successive layer has a higher frequency (lacunarity) and lower amplitude (persistence)." This creates detailed, wispy structures.

Coordinates are modulated through sinusoidal mesh warping—`sin()` and `cos()` functions apply time-based offsets to UV coordinates, making the noise "warps against itself" to simulate liquid surfaces.

## Color Blending

The implementation includes "8 shader-internal modes + 16 CSS container modes." Instead of simple linear interpolation, the fragment shader executes professional blend modes (Multiply, Screen, Overlay) directly, allowing colors to interact rather than just overlap for vibrant highlights and deep shadows.

## Configuration & Controls

An interactive panel provides:
- Four independent color pickers with preset themes
- Animation speed, turbulence, and detail (octaves) adjustment
- Lacunarity and mesh intensity parameters
- CSS blend modes and blur filters
- JSON import/export for settings

## Performance

All computation runs on the GPU with **zero dependencies**—pure JavaScript and WebGL. The 3-layer Simplex noise implementation targets 60 FPS on mobile and desktop hardware.

Links: [{"title":"backdrop-filter - CSS | MDN","url":"https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/Reference/Properties/backdrop-filter"},{"title":"Creating Blurred Backgrounds Using CSS Backdrop-Filter","url":"https://blog.openreplay.com/creating-blurred-backgrounds-css-backdrop-filter/"},{"title":"CSS Backdrop-Filter Blur Not Working with Overflow Hidden Parent: 2026 Complete Fix Guide","url":"https://copyprogramming.com/howto/transitioning-backdrop-filter-blur-on-an-element-with-overflow-hidden-parent-is-not-working"},{"title":"925025 - CSS blur filter is order of magnitude slower than Chrome","url":"https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=925025"},{"title":"How CSS Properties Affect Website Performance - F22 Labs","url":"https://www.f22labs.com/blogs/how-css-properties-affect-website-performance/"},{"title":"The translateZ trick • Michael Uloth","url":"https://michaeluloth.com/css-translate-z/"},{"title":"How to fix filter: blur() performance issue in Safari • Today I Learned","url":"https://graffino.com/til/how-to-fix-filter-blur-performance-issue-in-safari"},{"title":"1718471 - backdrop-filter: blur is laggy when many elements are rendered","url":"https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1718471"},{"title":"CSS Blur Filter: Complete Guide to Gaussian Blur Effects and Visual Applications - CodeLucky","url":"https://codelucky.com/css-blur-filter/"},{"title":"CSS Blur Effect Showcase: 41 Examples","url":"https://wpdean.com/css-blur-effect/"}]

I've completed a web search for your query about CSS filter blur, backdrop-filter, and performance optimization techniques. Here are the key findings:

## GPU Acceleration and Performance

Backdrop filters trigger GPU-accelerated compositing but can impact performance on mobile devices. In 2026, the golden rule for smooth animations remains unchanged: animate only properties that can be handled by the compositor thread, and transform and opacity are fully GPU-accelerated and maintain 60fps even on modest hardware.

## Optimization Strategies

Optimization strategies include using `will-change: backdrop-filter` as a hint for browser optimization and `transform: translateZ(0)` to force GPU layer creation. Apply will-change property only on elements that actually change to help browsers optimize rendering without wasting memory resources.

## Animation Considerations

Backdrop-filter animations should be avoided or minimized, as they trigger paint operations that bottleneck performance. Instead, animate the opacity() function within backdrop-filter or fade the element's opacity property instead of animating blur values directly, as these methods leverage GPU acceleration and avoid costly filter recalculations.

## Browser-Specific Notes

The basic reason translateZ(ANY_VALUE) makes the animation run smoothly is that it tells Safari to render the animation using the GPU instead of the CPU, and without translateZ Safari will try to animate your blur() filter using the CPU.

## Performance Limits

Mobile devices typically handle 3-5 simultaneous blur effects well while desktop systems can manage more, and you should monitor frame rates and reduce blur radius or element count if scrolling becomes choppy.

1→# OrbKit — Full Context Dump
     2→
     3→## Project Identity
     4→
     5→- **Name**: orbkit
     6→- **npm**: `orbkit` (available), `@orbkit/editor` for optional editor
     7→- **Repo**: `github.com/oryanmoshe/orbkit`
     8→- **Author**: Oryan Moshe (@oryanmoshe)
     9→- **What**: Composable, animated orb effects for React. Multi-orb scenes with per-orb control (blur, blend, waviness, drift). Optional visual editor. Multiple rendering backends (CSS, Canvas, WebGL).
    10→
    11→## Origin
    12→
    13→Extracted from DreamTeam.io's background customizer feature (branch: `background-customizer-9000` in `dreamteam-io-client`).
    14→
    15→---
    16→
    17→## Source Code Reference (DreamTeam.io)
    18→
    19→All source files live in `/Users/oryan/dev/dreamteam-io-workspace/dreamteam-io-client/src/`.
    20→
    21→### Core Rendering
    22→- `components/gradient-background/gradient-background-component.js` — Main renderer. Maps `backgroundTheme.points` to `<OrbLayer>` divs with deterministic elliptical drift animation + grain noise `<canvas>` overlay. Key constants: `REDACTED`, `MIN_DURATION=6`, `MIN_AMPLITUDE=2`, `MAX_AMPLITUDE=10`.
    23→- `components/gradient-background/gradient-background-component-styles.js` — styled-components. `GradientBackground` (absolute fill, z-index:-1), `OrbLayer` (130% size for edge overflow, mix-blend-mode:screen, CSS keyframe drift), `GrainCanvas` (mix-blend-mode:overlay).
    24→- `components/gradient-background/use-gradient-background-connector.js` — Redux connector. Reads `currentUser.settings.backgroundTheme`, merges with `previewTheme` from context.
    25→- `components/gradient-background/gradient-theme-context.js` — React context: `GradientThemeProvider` with `previewTheme`, `setLivePreview`, `clearLivePreview`.
    26→
    27→### Utilities (`utils/gradient-utils.js`)
    28→```javascript
    29→hexToHsl(hex)              // #RRGGBB → {h, s, l}
    30→hslToHex(h, s, l)          // HSL → #RRGGBB
    31→applySaturation(hex, sat)  // Adjust saturation 0-100
    32→generateGradientCSS(theme) // Full theme → CSS background string
    33→generateSingleOrbCSS(point, saturation) // Single point → radial-gradient CSS
    34→generateGrainIntensity(grain) // 0-100 → 0-0.5 opacity
    35→```
    36→
    37→### Presets (`constants/gradient-theme-presets.js`)
    38→5 built-in presets, each with: `name`, `label`, `backgroundColor`, `points[]`, `saturation`, `grain`, `breathing`.
    39→
    40→| Preset | Background | Colors | Saturation |
    41→|--------|-----------|--------|-----------|
    42→| Ocean | #1a1a1a | Blue, coral, cream | 70 |
    43→| Sunset | #1a1018 | Orange, pink, purple | 75 |
    44→| Forest | #0f1a14 | Dark green, green, cream | 60 |
    45→| Aurora | #0f0f1a | Purple, cyan, indigo | 80 |
    46→| Minimal | #1a1918 | Cream, gray, beige | 30 |
    47→
    48→Point data shape:
    49→```javascript
    50→{ id: "p1", color: "#4A90D9", position: { x: 0.2, y: 0.25 }, radius: 0.8 }
    51→```
    52→
    53→Theme data shape:
    54→```javascript
    55→{
    56→  version: 1,
    57→  preset: "ocean",
    58→  backgroundColor: "#1a1a1a",
    59→  points: [...],
    60→  saturation: 70,   // 0-100
    61→  grain: 35,         // 0-100
    62→  breathing: 30,     // 0-100
    63→}
    64→```
    65→
    66→### Editor — Main Component (`components/gradient-theme-editor/gradient-theme-editor-component.js`)
    67→- Renders inside app's `DrawerComponent` (width: 380px)
    68→- Sections: preset selector, randomize/save buttons, canvas with draggable points, color point editor, vibrancy slider, background color swatches (12 dark colors), grain slider, breathing slider
    69→- `randomizeTheme()` — generates 4-5 random points with random colors/positions
    70→- `randomHex()` — HSL-based random color (s: 40-100, l: 30-70)
    71→- Background colors: `["#0a0a0a", "#1a1a1a", "#2E2D2C", "#3D1C1C", "#1a1018", "#2D1B4E", "#0f0f1a", "#0C2340", "#0f1a14", "#1a2e1a", "#1a1918", "#3B2F20"]`
    72→
    73→### Editor — Canvas (`gradient-canvas/`)
    74→- `gradient-canvas-component.js` — Renders theme preview + draggable `PointHandle` circles
    75→- `use-gradient-canvas-state.js` — Mouse drag logic: `handlePointMouseDown`, `handleCanvasMouseDown` (click to add), `isDragging` state
    76→
    77→### Editor — Color Point Editor (`color-point-editor/`)
    78→- Color picker + radius slider for the currently selected point
    79→- Delete point button
    80→
    81→### Editor — Preset Selector (`theme-preset-selector/`)
    82→- Shows built-in presets + user-saved custom presets
    83→- Delete custom preset support
    84→
    85→### Editor — Floating Button (`theme-editor-floating-button/`)
    86→- FAB that opens the editor drawer
    87→
    88→---
    89→
    90→## Current Rendering Technique (Detail)
    91→
    92→### Orb Rendering
    93→Each orb = an absolutely positioned `<div>` at 130% parent size (for overflow), with:
    94→```css
    95→background: radial-gradient(at X% Y%, adjustedColor 0%, transparent radius%);
    96→mix-blend-mode: screen;
    97→```
    98→
    99→### Drift Animation
   100→Elliptical orbit via 8-step CSS keyframe:
   101→```
   102→0%     → translate(ax%, 0)
   103→12.5%  → translate(ax*0.707%, ay*0.707%)
   104→25%    → translate(0, ay%)
   105→37.5%  → translate(-ax*0.707%, ay*0.707%)
   106→50%    → translate(-ax%, 0)
   107→62.5%  → translate(-ax*0.707%, -ay*0.707%)
   108→75%    → translate(0, -ay%)
   109→87.5%  → translate(ax*0.707%, -ay*0.707%)
   110→100%   → translate(ax%, 0)
   111→```
   112→
   113→Orbit params seeded from point position (`seed = x*1000 + y*7919`), giving each point a unique but deterministic orbit shape.
   114→
   115→Duration: `baseDuration * (1 + index * 0.3)` — each successive orb is 30% slower, creating visual depth.
   116→Delay: `index * -baseDuration * 0.25` — staggered start for organic feel.
   117→
   118→### Grain Overlay
   119→Full-size `<canvas>` with random grayscale noise, rendered once + on resize. `mix-blend-mode: overlay`, opacity from grain setting (0-100 → 0-0.5).
   120→
   121→---
   122→
   123→## App-Specific Couplings to Remove
   124→
   125→1. **Redux** — `useGradientBackgroundConnector` reads `currentUser.settings.backgroundTheme`
   126→2. **Redux** — `useGradientThemeEditorConnector` dispatches save actions with debounce
   127→3. **styled-components** — All styles
   128→4. **App UI** — `DrawerComponent`, `SliderComponent` from internal component library
   129→5. **i18n** — `translate()` from internal translate service
   130→6. **lodash** — `map()` (trivial)
   131→
   132→---
   133→
   134→## Target Architecture
   135→
   136→### Tech Stack
   137→- **Language**: TypeScript (strict)
   138→- **Runtime/Package Manager**: Bun
   139→- **Build**: `bun build` (ESM + CJS outputs)
   140→- **Monorepo**: Bun workspaces
   141→- **Testing**: `bun test`
   142→- **Styling**: Zero opinion — vanilla CSS class names, consumers bring their own styling
   143→- **WebGL** (optional renderer): OGL or raw WebGL
   144→- **CI**: GitHub Actions
   145→
   146→### Package Structure
   147→```
   148→orbkit/
   149→├── .claude/
   150→│   └── CLAUDE.md
   151→├── .gitignore
   152→├── package.json              # Bun workspaces root
   153→├── tsconfig.json             # Base TS config
   154→├── README.md
   155→├── LICENSE                   # MIT
   156→│

   158→│   ├── core/                 # npm: orbkit
   159→│   │   ├── package.json
   160→│   │   ├── tsconfig.json
   161→│   │   └── src/
   162→│   │       ├── index.ts      # Public API exports
   163→│   │       ├── components/
   164→│   │       │   ├── orb-scene.tsx    # <OrbScene> — container/compositor
   165→│   │       │   ├── orb.tsx          # <Orb> — individual orb primitive
   166→│   │       │   ├── grain.tsx        # <Grain> — noise overlay
   167→│   │       │   └── index.ts
   168→│   │       ├── renderers/
   169→│   │       │   ├── css-renderer.ts      # Default renderer
   170→│   │       │   ├── canvas-renderer.ts   # Canvas 2D
   171→│   │       │   └── webgl-renderer.ts    # GLSL shaders
   172→│   │       ├── presets/
   173→│   │       │   └── index.ts
   174→│   │       └── utils/
   175→│   │           ├── color.ts
   176→│   │           └── animation.ts
   177→│   │
   178→│   └── editor/               # npm: @orbkit/editor (optional)
   179→│       ├── package.json
   180→│       ├── tsconfig.json
   181→│       └── src/
   182→│           ├── index.ts
   183→│           ├── orb-editor.tsx
   184→│           ├── canvas-preview.tsx
   185→│           └── color-picker.tsx
   186→│
   187→├── examples/
   188→│   └── basic/
   189→│
   190→└── docs/
   191→```
   192→
   193→### Target API
   194→
   195→```tsx
   196→// 1. Simple — preset-based
   197→<OrbScene preset="aurora" />
   198→
   199→// 2. Composable — full per-orb control
   200→<OrbScene background="#0f0f1a" grain={0.35} breathing={30}>
   201→  <Orb color="#7C3AED" position={[0.2, 0.25]} size={0.8} blur={40} />
   202→  <Orb color="#06B6D4" position={[0.75, 0.5]} size={0.75} blur={60} wavy />
   203→  <Orb color="#3730A3" position={[0.45, 0.85]} size={0.7} blur={20} />
   204→</OrbScene>
   205→
   206→// 3. Standalone orb (not just backgrounds)
   207→<Orb color="#FF6B35" size={200} wavy interactive />
   208→
   209→// 4. With optional editor
   210→import { OrbEditor } from '@orbkit/editor';
   211→<OrbEditor scene={sceneRef} />
   212→
   213→// 5. Programmatic control
   214→const scene = useOrbScene({ preset: 'ocean' });
   215→scene.addOrb({ color: '#FF0000', position: [0.5, 0.5] });
   216→scene.removeOrb('orb-id');
   217→scene.setBreathing(50);
   218→```
   219→
   220→### Per-Orb Props
   221→| Prop | Type | Description |
   222→|------|------|-------------|
   223→| `color` | `string` | Hex color |
   224→| `position` | `[number, number]` | Normalized [x, y] 0-1 |
   225→| `size` | `number` | Orb spread radius (0-1 normalized or px) |
   226→| `blur` | `number` | Per-orb fuzziness (px) — CSS `filter: blur()` |
   227→| `blendMode` | `string` | `'screen'` \| `'overlay'` \| `'soft-light'` \| etc. |
   228→| `wavy` | `boolean \| WavyConfig` | Organic edge animation. `{ scale, speed, intensity }` |
   229→| `drift` | `boolean \| DriftConfig` | Orbit animation. `{ speed, amplitude, direction }` or false |
   230→| `renderer` | `'css' \| 'canvas' \| 'webgl'` | Per-orb renderer override |
   231→| `interactive` | `boolean` | Mouse hover effects |
   232→| `className` | `string` | Custom CSS class |
   233→
   234→### Scene Props
   235→| Prop | Type | Description |
   236→|------|------|-------------|
   237→| `background` | `string` | Background color |
   238→| `grain` | `number` | Noise overlay 0-1 |
   239→| `breathing` | `number` | Global animation intensity 0-100 |
   240→| `preset` | `string` | Named preset |
   241→| `renderer` | `string` | Default renderer for all children |
   242→| `className` | `string` | Custom CSS class |
   243→| `style` | `CSSProperties` | Inline styles |
   244→| `as` | `'div' \| 'section' \| etc.` | Render as different element |
   245→
   246→---
   247→
   248→## Rendering Approaches (Detail)
   249→
   250→### CSS Renderer (Default)
   251→- Each orb: `<div>` with `radial-gradient` + `filter: blur(Xpx)` + `mix-blend-mode`
   252→- Drift: CSS `@keyframes` with elliptical path
   253→- Waviness: SVG `<feTurbulence>` + `<feDisplacementMap>` filter applied per-orb
   254→- Grain: `<canvas>` with random noise, `mix-blend-mode: overlay`
   255→- Pros: SSR compatible, zero deps, best performance, works everywhere
   256→- Cons: Limited organic effects compared to WebGL
   257→
   258→### Canvas Renderer
   259→- Single `<canvas>`, each orb drawn as gaussian-blurred circle
   260→- Blending via canvas composite operations (`globalCompositeOperation`)
   261→- Grain on same canvas
   262→- Pros: Better blending control, single DOM element
   263→- Cons: No SSR, slightly more CPU
   264→
   265→### WebGL Renderer
   266→- GLSL fragment shaders per orb (or single multi-orb shader)
   267→- Simplex noise (`snoise3`) for organic waviness
   268→- GPU-accelerated, most beautiful effects
   269→- Mouse interactivity via shader uniforms
   270→- Pros: Highest quality, GPU performance, organic effects
   271→- Cons: WebGL dependency, no SSR, OGL or similar needed
   272→
   273→---
   274→
   275→## ReactBits Orb Reference Implementation
   276→
   277→ReactBits Orb uses **OGL** (minimal WebGL renderer) + custom **GLSL fragment shader**.
   278→
   279→### Full Shader Technique
   280→```glsl
   281→// Simplex noise for waviness
   282→float n0 = snoise3(vec3(uv * noiseScale, iTime * 0.5)) * 0.5 + 0.5;
   283→// Noise modulates orb edge radius over time
   284→float r0 = mix(mix(innerRadius, 1.0, 0.4), mix(innerRadius, 1.0, 0.6), n0);
   285→
   286→// Two lighting functions for depth
   287→float light1(float intensity, float attenuation, float dist) {
   288→  return intensity / (1.0 + dist * attenuation);
   289→}
   290→float light2(float intensity, float attenuation, float dist) {
   291→  return intensity / (1.0 + dist * dist * attenuation);
   292→}
   293→
   294→// Hover distortion via sin waves
   295→uv.x += hover * hoverIntensity * 0.1 * sin(uv.y * 10.0 + iTime);
   296→uv.y += hover * hoverIntensity * 0.1 * sin(uv.x * 10.0 + iTime);
   297→```
   298→
   299→### Color System
   300→- 3 base colors blended dynamically
   301→- YIQ color space for hue rotation (`rgb2yiq` → rotate → `yiq2rgb`)
   302→- `adjustHue(color, hueDeg)` rotates hue in YIQ space
   303→
   304→### Props
   305→```tsx
   306→<Orb
   307→  hue={0}                    // Hue rotation in degrees
   308→  hoverIntensity={0.2}       // Distortion strength on hover
   309→  rotateOnHover={true}       // Rotation animation on hover
   310→  forceHoverState={false}    // Always show hover effect
   311→  backgroundColor="#000000"  // Background blend color
   312→/>
   313→```
   314→
   315→Single orb only, no composition, no editor, no presets.
   316→
   317→---
   318→
   319→## Competitive Landscape
   320→
   321→| Package | Stars | What | Missing vs OrbKit |
   322→|---------|-------|------|-------------------|
   323→| react-ai-orb | Low | Single animated AI orb | No multi-orb, no editor, no presets |
   324→| react-gradient-animation | ~200 | Animated gradient background | No orb positioning, no per-orb control, no editor |
   325→| React Bits Orb | Part of collection | WebGL single orb with waviness | No composition, no editor, no presets |
   326→| @mesh-gradient/core | Low | WebGL mesh gradients (SwiftUI-style) | Different technique entirely, no orbs |
   327→| easy-mesh-gradient | Low | CSS mesh gradient utility | Utility only, no React component |
   328→| animated-gradient | Low | Linear gradient color transitions | Linear only, no orbs |
   329→| @blur-ui/mesh-gradient | Low | Apple-style mesh gradient | Single mesh, no orb concept |
   330→
   331→**OrbKit's unique value: composable multi-orb + per-orb effects (blur, blend, wavy) + visual editor + multiple rendering backends + presets**
   332→
   333→---
   334→
   335→## Effort Estimate
   336→
   337→| Task | Days | Notes |
   338→|------|------|-------|
   339→| Project scaffold (Bun, TS, workspace) | 0.5 | |
   340→| Extract core renderer from DreamTeam | 1 | Port gradient-utils, presets, animation math |
   341→| Per-orb blur + blend modes | 1 | CSS `filter` + `mix-blend-mode` props |
   342→| SVG filter waviness (CSS renderer) | 1-2 | `feTurbulence` + `feDisplacementMap` |
   343→| WebGL renderer with GLSL shaders | 3-5 | Simplex noise, multi-orb support |
   344→| TypeScript types + build config | 0.5 | |
   345→| Editor extraction + headless | 2-3 | Remove styled-components, make generic |
   346→| Docs site + examples | 2-3 | |
   347→| **Total** | **~2 weeks** | |
   348→
   349→---
   350→
   351→## Key Design Decisions
   352→
   353→1. **Bun over pnpm/tsup** — Single tool for package management, workspaces, bundling, testing. Simpler toolchain.
   354→2. **CSS-first renderer** — SSR compatible, zero deps, works everywhere. WebGL as progressive enhancement.
   355→3. **Composable over config** — `<OrbScene><Orb /><Orb /></OrbScene>` over `<OrbScene config={{points: [...]}} />`. Both should work.
   356→4. **Zero styling opinion** — Vanilla CSS class names. No styled-components, no Tailwind dependency. Consumers style however they want.
   357→5. **Per-orb fuzziness** — Each orb gets its own `filter: blur()` instead of shared radial-gradient transparency.
   358→6. **Per-orb blend mode** — Not just `screen` for all. Expose `overlay`, `soft-light`, `multiply`, etc.
   359→7. **Waviness via SVG filters (CSS mode)** — `feTurbulence` for organic edges without WebGL dependency.
   360→8. **Optional editor** — Separate package, not bundled with core. Import only if needed.
